commit_message:
keystone-manage doctor

This introduces a new keystone-manage command called 'doctor' which
attempts to diagnose and report on various ill-advised configurations
and deployment states.

The number of checks we could perform is basically endless, so this is
just a random sampling of checks to get the ball rolling. The idea is
that as new features are introduced, as default configurations change,
as we have new recommendations to make to deployers, etc, we can
implement new checks in keystone-manage doctor and communicate our
concerns directly to those operated affected deployments.

Change-Id: Ib6660c1a885c439ca03357870628b2ea52e39e9d
Implements: bp keystone-manage-doctor

added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import keystone.conf from keystone.token.providers.fernet import utils as fernet_utils CONF = keystone.conf.CONF def symptom_usability_of_Fernet_key_repository(): """Fernet key repository is not setup correctly. The Fernet key repository is expected to be readable by the user running keystone, but not world-readable, because it contains security-sensitive secrets. """ return ( 'fernet' in CONF.token.provider and not fernet_utils.validate_key_repository()) def symptom_keys_in_Fernet_key_repository(): """Fernet key repository is empty. After configuring keystone to use the Fernet token provider, you should use `keystone-manage fernet_setup` to initially populate your key repository with keys, and periodically rotate your keys with `keystone-manage fernet_rotate`. """ return ( 'fernet' in CONF.token.provider and not fernet_utils.load_keys())

commit_message:
rename a file for fedora guests

fedora guests don't use upstart. renaming the file because the current
name (20-guest-upstart) while identical to the name for the ubuntu
file is confusing and misleading.

Change-Id: I9818235e0d367c8213ccd1f60c4b26be11dd3735

commit_message:
Fix the bug of 'AttributeError' when connect volume

Since 'ISCSIConnector' object has no attribute 'host_device', we
can use the parameter 'device_name' instead when we can't find a
multipath device.

Change-Id: I17eef252e127f9741883778a622d4666cd348cd1
Closes-Bug: #1593643

commit_message:
trunk: add more registry callbacks to trunk plugin

This patch adds more callbacks to trunk plugin which is necessary for
opendaylight support.
- Adds PRECOMMIT event
- add trunk resource when add/delete_subports to its argument

Partially-implements: blueprint vlan-aware-vms
Change-Id: I8f077bae26d441a4906278d6ab448876324c216e

subject: Git mv'd all bootstrap dir files into services dir
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-18 19:03:57.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/35c0cb566b6d32c54d23755ed7c5bac33b6d2870', 'message': "Git mv'd all bootstrap dir files into services dir

- No bug-fixes,blue-prints, nor code changes.
- Originally, kolla-kubernetes only used 3 types of kubernetes
resource files (job, pod, svc).  Bootstrap files (job) were separated
from service files (pod, svc).  Subcommands were tied directly to the
files their respective directories (bootstrap command -> ./bootstrap
dir, run command -> ./services dir).
- This was done because of the way kolla-kubernetes used to work.
Upon subcommand launch, all of the files in its respective
directory were jinja processed and then loaded into kubernetes (in
random order).
- Now that we have added a bunch of resources that require ordering
(disk, pv, pvc, etc), and kolla-kubernetes directly references each
type of file based on the configuration of
./etc/kolla-kubernetes/kolla-kubernetes.yml, we no longer need to
separate bootstarp and service files.

Change-Id: I595388a686330cfdeb662b9a0a8b52cc1d45c913
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-07-19 17:25:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/0a744ab45334da7f1d20d62008ab2a721a74832c', 'message': "Git mv'd all bootstrap dir files into services dir

- No bug-fixes, blue-prints, nor code changes.
- Originally, kolla-kubernetes only used 3 types of kubernetes
resource files (job, pod, svc).  Bootstrap files (job) were separated
from service files (pod, svc).  Subcommands were tied directly to the
files their respective directories (bootstrap command -> ./bootstrap
dir, run command -> ./services dir).
- This was done because of the way kolla-kubernetes used to work.
Upon subcommand launch, all of the files in its respective
directory were jinja processed and then loaded into kubernetes (in
random order).
- Now that we have added a bunch of resources that require ordering
(disk, pv, pvc, etc), and kolla-kubernetes directly references each
type of file based on the configuration of
./etc/kolla-kubernetes/kolla-kubernetes.yml, we no longer need to
separate bootstrap and service files.

Change-Id: I595388a686330cfdeb662b9a0a8b52cc1d45c913
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2016-07-19 17:35:13.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-kubernetes/commit/338c61205dc48a03b17ebd9f0e2cbd55796d41ac', 'message': "Git mv'd all bootstrap dir files into services dir

- No bug-fixes, blue-prints, nor code changes.
- Originally, kolla-kubernetes only used 3 types of kubernetes
resource files (job, pod, svc).  Bootstrap files (job) were separated
from service files (pod, svc).  Subcommands were tied directly to the
files their respective directories (bootstrap command -> ./bootstrap
dir, run command -> ./services dir).
- This was done because of the way kolla-kubernetes used to work.
Upon subcommand launch, all of the files in its respective
directory were jinja processed and then loaded into kubernetes (in
random order).
- Now that we have added a bunch of resources that require ordering
(disk, pv, pvc, etc), and kolla-kubernetes directly references each
type of file based on the configuration of
./etc/kolla-kubernetes/kolla-kubernetes.yml, we no longer need to
separate bootstrap and service files.

Change-Id: I595388a686330cfdeb662b9a0a8b52cc1d45c913

- Originally, kolla-kubernetes only used 3 types of kubernetes
resource files (job, pod, svc).  Bootstrap files (job) were separated
from service files (pod, svc).  Subcommands were tied directly to the
files their respective directories (bootstrap command -> ./bootstrap
dir, run command -> ./services dir).

Upon subcommand launch, all of the files in its respective
directory were jinja processed and then loaded into kubernetes (in
random order).

(disk, pv, pvc, etc), and kolla-kubernetes directly references each
type of file based on the configuration of
./etc/kolla-kubernetes/kolla-kubernetes.yml, we no longer need to
separate bootstrap and service files.

commit_message:
Git mv'd all bootstrap dir files into services dir

- No bug-fixes, blue-prints, nor code changes.
- Originally, kolla-kubernetes only used 3 types of kubernetes
resource files (job, pod, svc).  Bootstrap files (job) were separated
from service files (pod, svc).  Subcommands were tied directly to the
files their respective directories (bootstrap command -> ./bootstrap
dir, run command -> ./services dir).
- This was done because of the way kolla-kubernetes used to work.
Upon subcommand launch, all of the files in its respective
directory were jinja processed and then loaded into kubernetes (in
random order).
- Now that we have added a bunch of resources that require ordering
(disk, pv, pvc, etc), and kolla-kubernetes directly references each
type of file based on the configuration of
./etc/kolla-kubernetes/kolla-kubernetes.yml, we no longer need to
separate bootstrap and service files.

Change-Id: I595388a686330cfdeb662b9a0a8b52cc1d45c913

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: fix JSONEncodedDict implementation type

It's actually Text, not String, as correctly written in migration
scripts.

This fixes an error on MySQL as String is converted to VARCHAR which
requires a length.

Change-Id: I5f5d7902c647ba0b7a214bca21d0df1cc96fc57c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/13/344413/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: impl = String

commit_message:
Use bundletester for amulet test execution

Switch to using bundletester for execution of functional tests,
leveraging tox to build out test virtualenvs.

Rename amulet tests inline with gate-*, dev-* and dfs-*
naming standards.

Update README to refer to functional testing section of the charm
guide.

Change-Id: Id617a634f7d12e8acab07ee121f9fd38b8380c17

commit_message:
Implement Date Filters for Secrets

This CR implements the spec for date filters.  The only difference
between the spec and this CR is the use of the alternative ISO format
(without the "Z") for specifying the dates.  This change was made to
have a more consistent API since the Zulu designation is not used
anywhere in the API where dates are shown to the user.  Additionaly the
libraries used for date-time parsing do not make use of the Zulu
designation either.

Implements: blueprint date-filters
DocImpact
APIImpact

Change-Id: Ic8fbe3d0e8b309bb192aaddf30291d1333756064

added_lines: from barbican.api.controllers import secretsclass WhenValidatingDateFilters(utils.BarbicanAPIBaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(WhenValidatingDateFilters, self).setUp() self.controller = secrets.SecretsController() def test_validates_plain_timestamp(self): date_filter = '2016-01-01T00:00:00' self.assertTrue(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validates_gt_and_lt_timestamps(self): date_filter = 'gt:2016-01-01T00:00:00,lt:2016-12-31T00:00:00' self.assertTrue(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validates_gte_and_lte_timestamps(self): date_filter = 'gte:2016-01-01T00:00:00,lte:2016-12-31T00:00:00' self.assertTrue(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_two_plain_timestamps(self): date_filter = '2016-01-01T00:00:00,2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_two_gt_timestamps(self): date_filter = 'gt:2016-01-01T00:00:00,gt:2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_two_lt_timestamps(self): date_filter = 'lt:2016-01-01T00:00:00,lt:2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_two_gte_timestamps(self): date_filter = 'gte:2016-01-01T00:00:00,gte:2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_two_lte_timestamps(self): date_filter = 'lte:2016-01-01T00:00:00,lte:2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_plain_and_gte_timestamps(self): date_filter = '2016-01-01T00:00:00,gte:2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) date_filter = 'gte:2016-01-01T00:00:00,2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_plain_and_lte_timestamps(self): date_filter = '2016-01-01T00:00:00,lte:2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) date_filter = 'lte:2016-01-01T00:00:00,2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_gt_and_gte_timestamps(self): date_filter = 'gt:2016-01-01T00:00:00,gte:2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_lt_and_lte_timestamps(self): date_filter = 'lt:2016-01-01T00:00:00,lte:2016-01-02T00:00:00' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) def test_validation_fails_with_bogus_timestamp(self): date_filter = 'bogus' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_date_filter(date_filter)) class WhenValidatingSortFilters(utils.BarbicanAPIBaseTestCase): def setUp(self): super(WhenValidatingSortFilters, self).setUp() self.controller = secrets.SecretsController() def test_validates_name_sorting(self): sorting = 'name' self.assertTrue(self.controller._is_valid_sorting(sorting)) def test_validation_fails_for_bogus_attribute(self): sorting = 'bogus' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_sorting(sorting)) def test_validation_fails_for_duplicate_keys(self): sorting = 'name,name:asc' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_sorting(sorting)) def test_validation_fails_for_too_many_colons(self): sorting = 'name:asc:foo' self.assertFalse(self.controller._is_valid_sorting(sorting))

Due to the os-extended-volumes API it is necessary to be able to
retrieve block device mapping info for an instance at any time. In order
to do so it needs to be stored with the build request.

This also makes it available during instance deletion where it may be
useful to look up whether delete_on_termination is set on a bdm so that
it can be cleaned up.

commit_message:
Add block_device_mappings to BuildRequest

Due to the os-extended-volumes API it is necessary to be able to
retrieve block device mapping info for an instance at any time. In order
to do so it needs to be stored with the build request.

This also makes it available during instance deletion where it may be
useful to look up whether delete_on_termination is set on a bdm so that
it can be cleaned up.

Change-Id: Ib774a43e49b7153b3f7b099a59483c62003ee7a8
Partially-Implements: bp add-buildrequest-obj

commit_message:
First implementation of run_tests.sh

run_tests.sh script now replaces what we had in JJB definition. For now,
it has feature parity with how we used to test cookiecutter. It might
evolve in the future.

Change-Id: Ie9ab5b32c0434534c90885b7fbbf2d897b52b5a6

commit_message:
Bump openstacksdk to 0.9.0

Bump openstacksdk global requirement to 0.9.0 in order to pull
in new network resources to be used by OSC.

Change-Id: I4819fe612055e0357b5d8cc45524e1fbe7368b45
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-client-rbac

commit_message:
Fix wrong exception return in fixed_ips v2 extention

This kind of revert commit 378681490b043a5a51a9f58fba138310c20ea235.

The general idea for this revert is that the current code exposes which
SQL database is backing Nova. If Postgre, a HTTPBadRequest can be
raised, whilst with MySQL only a HTTPNotFound can be raised. We don't
want the API to depend on which SQL server is used.

This bug was already fixed by I9aa14bea2f29f1df85dfd1f07eb0b1947d2c1100
and I83d532c28c9aec690e8e1ffad8b58e71d619d728 but
I7b18b76745f9092456d511ad023a9ed3a24cca84 introduced the regression.

Changing the returned status code back and forth got unoticed by Tempest
because of the change Iafd2fb82ad5d50c2f4b3f0819ac7a6f8aa901264

Change-Id: I191b626a471626f334e4835fab602acea505ff78

commit_message:
libvirt: Rollback on dest host after deleting vm during live migration

If the VM is deleted during live migration process, there are remaining
garbage on destination host. This patch improves live_migration_monitor
to handle 'deletion process during live migration' by calling proper
rollback. This functionality are also covered by unit tests.

Change-Id: I6dcdb5ece512d074ff25aa9f6313c7b759d8a73a
Closes-Bug: #1285000

subject: Don't use memcached for caching metadata for now
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-26 20:19:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/26c3d5a64831cb42ea4f719b67bc73c8592e4887', 'message': 'Don't use memcached for caching metadata for now

The caching backend for memcached/dogpile stores whole Python objects
by creating a deep copy. At the moment Metadata is cached by storing the metadata
Python object, and therefore the whole object tree underneath,
including the "instance" attribute.  Whenever the metadata is
fetched, it also fetches the old version of instance with it, and
works on it. This has several implications, like for example lazy
fetched fields of the "instance" object are never cached, if they are
not pre-fetched before caching.  Also it might implicate security
issues. Until this is fixed by correctly caching pure data

commit_message:
Don't use memcached for caching metadata for now

The caching backend for memcached/dogpile stores whole Python objects
by creating a deep copy.  At the moment Metadata is cached by storing
the metadata Python object, and therefore the whole object tree
underneath, including the "instance" attribute.  Whenever the
metadata is fetched, it also fetches the old version of instance with
it, and works on it.  This has several implications, like for example
lazy fetched fields of the "instance" object are never cached, if
they are not pre-fetched before caching.  Also it might implicate
security issues.  Until this is fixed by correctly caching pure data
structures, this patch forces to use the internal cache (based on a
Python dict), which doesn't have these issues.

BUMP

Change-Id: If853be1693f3673a9392b985b9035e1ada8e2a93
Closes-Bug: #1549814

commit_message:
Avoid parallel DB queries of identical metadata

If several metadata request come in, and the data is not in the cache
yet, each of them trigger their own database query.  This patch
synchronizes the metadata access in order to block subsequent
identical cache queries until the cache is populated.

Change-Id: Iafb530e7431bbe95f2e0af51e979649591f95597
Related-Bug: #1549814

deleted_lines: data = self._cache.get(cache_key) if data: LOG.debug("Using cached metadata for %s", address) try: data = base.get_metadata_by_address(address) except exception.NotFound: return None if CONF.metadata_cache_expiration > 0: self._cache.set(cache_key, data) return data data = self._cache.get(cache_key) if data: LOG.debug("Using cached metadata for instance %s", instance_id) try: data = base.get_metadata_by_instance_id(instance_id, address) except exception.NotFound: return None if CONF.metadata_cache_expiration > 0: self._cache.set(cache_key, data) return data

commit_message:
VMware: speed up start of n-cpu

When booting a nova-compute node and say for example there are 1024 VMs
running on that node, the node may take upto 2 hours to actually start
to work.

This patch does the instance sync with the DB in the background.

Change-Id: I8fd4e97d327680ecf7aeccaf643850938d61595f
Closes-Bug: #1513735

commit_message:
Libvirt: enable error_policy option for instances

This allows the administrator to set the libvirt driver error_policy
that controls how libvirt handles I/O errors. The administrator may
set the new option 'io_error_policy' in the [libvirt] section to any
of the known error_policy options.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint libvirt-enable-error-policy-option
Change-Id: I6bf43910d74f5069cbf212db8c162115b60c6aba
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/44/258144/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: cfg.StrOpt('io_error_policy', choices=('stop', 'report', 'ignore', 'enospace'), help='Libvirt policy for handling disk read/write errors.'), self.io_error_policy = CONF.libvirt.io_error_policy info.driver_error_policy = self.io_error_policy info.driver_error_policy = self.io_error_policy

commit_message:
Move the shutdown_retry_interval to nova.conf

The shutdown_retry_interval is time to wait in seconds before
re-issuing a shutdown signal to an instance during power off.
The overall time to wait is set by CONF.shutdown_timeout.

But the instance shutdown_retry_interval param is defined as a
constant in the ComputeManager class. I think we should move it
to the nova.conf file, so we can config it by ourselves. It will
be set to 10 seconds if the value is bigger than
CONF.shutdown_timeout.

DocImpact

This patch will impact the nova.conf file.

Change-Id: Ib8c4c9d93256ed1707e065e39760ba5034b26545
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/71/272071/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

' 'Re-issuing a shutdown singal to an instance if the ' 'shutdown operation failed during shutdown_timeout.') retry_interval = CONF.shutdown_retry_interval
deleted_lines: 'image_volume_cache_enabled configuration option.') # How long to wait in seconds before re-issuing a shutdown # signal to an instance during power off. commit_message:
Use constraints for coverage job

OpenStack CI supports now constraints in the coverage job - as a first
job to check that recent changes for zuul-cloner work correctly.

Use constraints for cover environment. If this works successfully, the
other environments can be updated in followups.

Change-Id: I6069bee0a89d38f6a3ec57418e7bda9850dc6f64

commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).

Partial-Bug: #1259292
Change-Id: I8e2bc747ed6fba8f813c46aa6b172f9a2e0b725f

commit_message:
Add maxcpus support for qemu/kvm

Currently nova doesn't support cpu hotplug for qemu/kvm, the patch is
to add maxcpus to qemu command line once the hw:max_vcpus is set inside
the extra specs of flavor. By now we're only able to add vcpu to
qemu/kvm's instance via qemu-monitor-command.

The blueprint is
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/add-maxvcpus-flavor-extra-specs

Change-Id: I805652c603eff753fe88fba4414b80cf4ec224c5

commit_message:
Always set br-ex mtu including for grenade runs

Previously we were only setting the mtu on br-ex if not running grenade.
But now neutron runs multinode grenade tests so need to have br-ex's mtu
set appropriately for grenade and devstack both.

This is done by using PUBLIC_DEVICE_MTU devstack variable that will
guarantee the bridge is set appropriately in both devstack and grenade
cases.

Change-Id: I9bcc47303a6ce1f0b3125ad374adcc2e7ca654ac
Depends-On: I38a80bac18673a30842a7b997d0669fed5aff976
Related-Bug: #1603268
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/24/343024/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ "$DEVSTACK_GATE_TOPOLOGY" == "multinode" ]] && [[ $DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON -eq "1" ]]; then # Reduce the MTU on br-ex to match the MTU of the neutron private # network tunnels. Note we do this after devstack/grenade have run # to ensure that br-ex is present. echo "PUBLIC_BRIDGE_MTU=$EXTERNAL_BRIDGE_MTU" >>"$localrc_file" fi
deleted_lines: if [[ "$DEVSTACK_GATE_TOPOLOGY" == "multinode" ]] && [[ $DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON -eq "1" ]]; then # Reduce the MTU on br-ex to match the MTU of the neutron private # network tunnels. Note we do this after devstack/grenade have run # to ensure that br-ex is present. # TODO(afazekas): Configure the mtu smarter on the devstack side MTU_NODES=primary if [[ "$DEVSTACK_GATE_NEUTRON_DVR" -eq "1" ]]; then MTU_NODES=all fi $ANSIBLE "$MTU_NODES" -f 5 -i "$WORKSPACE/inventory" -m shell \ -a "sudo ip link set mtu $EXTERNAL_BRIDGE_MTU dev br-ex" fi

commit_message:
Handle 404 responses from neutron when polling for floating IPs

Neutron may respond with a 404 error when polled for floating IPs when
the L3 service plugin is not installed. This was handled in
get_floating_ip method, but not in the other methods. This patch adds
code to handle it also inside get_floating_ips_by_address and
get_floating_ips_by_project.

Change-Id: Iddf1c4cbf99b55b231745ae7a1186ac519c56b94
Closes-bug: #1488537

subject: Introduce PUBLIC_BRIDGE_MTU variable to set br-ex MTU
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-15 21:32:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/48f4b322e9655b246d6bdda170ae1f8a574175b7', 'message': 'Introduce PUBLIC_BRIDGE_MTU variable to set br-ex MTU

This variable can be used to accommodate for underlying infrastructure
that does not provide full 1500-sized traffic, or maybe instead gives
access to Jumbo frames.

Conflicts:
	lib/neutron_plugins/linuxbridge_agent

that does not provide full 1500-sized traffic, or maybe instead gives
access to Jumbo frames.

commit_message:
[doc] Prettify logical flow examples

Rather than showing database objects, use the output of ovn-sbctl
lflow-list, because it is prettier.

Change-Id: I243b7316731c6c723bf6e64c9326800272643578

commit_message:
Fix deleted non-public flavor lookups for non-admin users

This makes flavor lookups respect the "read_deleted" argument even
in non-admin contexts, by removing it as a constraint on the
relationship between the tables.  This should allow non-admin project
members to view details on deleted flavors when they are asking for
them, e.g., on running instances that were booted against flavors
that were subsequently deleted/edited.

It also adds an explicit flavor access check on lookups to ensure
that the requesting user has currently valid access to the flavor.
This will prevent users from booting/resizing instances onto flavors
where they previously had permissions, but no longer do.

Closes-Bug: 1366168
Change-Id: I14a9b20bb8d78d77d44c077805cdb6dec8436582

commit_message:
live-migration: Update instance availability_zone

This uses availability_zones package to find instance's az info
and update database record in post_live_migration_at_destination.

Co-Authored-By: Pawel Koniszewski <pawel.koniszewski@intel.com>
Change-Id: I146a66eff21ddbc396f90997a4aa728cbef61ad4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/41/254041/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import availability_zones as az instance_az = az.get_host_availability_zone(context, self.host) instance.availability_zone = instance_az

commit_message:
No direct XML parsing in libvirt driver

Add a pep8 test to check that no code in the libvirt driver does any
direct XML parsing. nova.virt.libvirt.config classes should be used.

This test will fail until all existing occurences of direct XML
parsing are replaced with corresponding config classes. This patch is
therefore WIP until if and when such changes are made.

Change-Id: I69ed148aa46441c2ae769b80ae7154be5933371b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/62/290562/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: xpath_find = (re.compile(r'\.find(all)?\("[^"]+"\)'), re.compile(r"\.find(all)?\('[^']+'\)"))def no_xpath_in_libvirt(logical_line, filename): """Check libvirt driver doesn't do any custom XML parsing N349 """ if "nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py" in filename: for regex in xpath_find: if regex.search(logical_line): yield(0, 'N349: nova.virt.libvirt.config classes must be used' ' instead of custom XML parsing') register(no_xpath_in_libvirt)

commit_message:
Case-insensitive filters

Hostnames provided to the scheduler with the ignore_hosts, force_hosts, and
force_nodes options are now matched in a case-insensitive manner

Change-Id: Iea279cbb7fe4012b139cfb0cbd3efc259b4b3899
Closes-Bug: #1464348
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/25/201725/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ignore_hosts = set(host_string.lower() for host_string in filter_properties.get('ignore_hosts', [])) force_hosts = set(host_string.lower() for host_string in filter_properties.get('force_hosts', [])) force_nodes = set(host_string.lower() for host_string in filter_properties.get('force_nodes', [])) if host.host.lower() not in ignore_hosts] if not force_hosts or host.host.lower() in force_hosts] if not force_nodes or host.nodename.lower() in force_nodes]
deleted_lines: ignore_hosts = set(filter_properties.get('ignore_hosts', [])) force_hosts = set(filter_properties.get('force_hosts', [])) force_nodes = set(filter_properties.get('force_nodes', [])) if host.host not in ignore_hosts] if not force_hosts or host.host in force_hosts] if not force_nodes or host.nodename in force_nodes]

the proposed neutron-ironic port mapping function. Basically it does
the following:

-- Simplifys the mac assignment process. A NIC's mac address is
determined by the port mapping function

-- supports portgroups, and it prefers ironic portgroup over ironic
port when mapping a neutron port.

-- Generates the instance's configdrive with the support of
network_data.json. In addition, vlan links are supported in the

commit_message:
[WIP] use neutron ironic port mapping

This is a prototype implementation on the nova ironic driver side for
the proposed neutron-ironic port mapping function. Basically it does
the following:

-- Simplifys the mac assignment process. A NIC's mac address is
determined by the port mapping function

-- supports portgroups, and it prefers ironic portgroup over ironic
port when mapping a neutron port.

-- Generates the instance's configdrive with the support of
network_data.json. In addition, vlan links are supported in the
network_data.json file.

Related-Bug: 1552364

Change-Id: Ie3ef45ac4670327229d73f88b40afec1dc4a455a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/287408/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: macs = self.driver.macs_for_instance(instance)

to pci data sync between pci device table and PciDeviceStats objects.

consistent way.

Move logic from nova.pci.stats.PciDeviceStats.consume_requests()
to the nova.pci.manager.PciDevTracker._claim_for_instance() method
using pci devices instead of pci pools.
Add PciDevTracker.get_free_devs() method which returns list of
available pci devices

This change is a second step to move from PciDeviceStats
implementation of the logic related to pci resources claim. After
this patch all the functionality will be transfered from PciDeviceStats
class to PciDevTracker and PciDevicePoolList classes. Migration to
non-PciDeviceStats implementation will make us free from the bugs related
to pci data sync between pci device table and PciDeviceStats objects.
Also it will make us be able to represent all system resources in a
consistent way.

Change-Id: I71cf7526286e2b1140804e7aeac93c11dd8b7583
Implements: blueprint pci-stats-generate

commit_message:
Move logic of pci consume_requests to manager

Move logic from nova.pci.stats.PciDeviceStats.consume_requests()
to the nova.pci.manager.PciDevTracker._claim_for_instance() method
using pci devices instead of pci pools.
Add PciDevTracker.get_free_devs() method which returns list of
available pci devices.
Remove consume_requests method from PciDeviceStats class

This change is a second step to move from PciDeviceStats
implementation of the logic related to pci resources claim. After
this patch all the functionality will be transfered from PciDeviceStats
class to PciDevTracker and PciDevicePoolList classes. Migration to
non-PciDeviceStats implementation will make us free from the bugs related
to pci data sync between pci device table and PciDeviceStats objects.
Also it will make us be able to represent all system resources in a
consistent way.

Change-Id: I71cf7526286e2b1140804e7aeac93c11dd8b7583
Implements: blueprint pci-stats-generate

commit_message:
XenAPI: create vdistore to stream vhd files

It uses xapi plugin running in dom0 to download image for vdi
creation in current implement. It requires additional disk space
in dom0 to hold the downloaded image. Now we can use the stream
in compute node to download image fram glance and stream data to
XAPI service; and also we can use stream to upload vhd to glance
to create new image.

Change-Id: Id7c96551f369981f023842cd4e10d005cb0e190f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/266283/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Moved live_migration_cleanup_flags to driver class

live_migration_cleanup_flags method was located in compute
manager class, while operation libvirt specific migrate_data
attributes. It could cause problems in other drivers, because
they doesn't invoke drivers cleanup method properly.

Closes-bug: #1487477
Closes-bug: #1542415

Change-Id: Ie0843fbd2edfcb77bb6036697adc297997a9af4f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/29/216329/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add expected_task_state for instance.save() used by block_device_mapping

When an instance was asked to be delete during it is
launching, we observed that the vm_state and
task_state of that instance has changed abnormally
like this:

When we delete the instance while its' task state
is networking:
scheduling->none->（networking）->deleting->
block_device_mapping-->spawing-->none

The expected task_state should be:
networking->deleting->deleted

and the vm_state changes like this:
BUILD-ACTIVE-disappear ,
which is also very strange for user.

This is due to the instance.save()
used by block_device_mapping doesn't
contain expected_task_state, it will
overwrite the DELETING task_state.

This patch adds expected_task_state
for instance.save() used by
block_device_mapping, by doing this,
the task_state of deleting will not
be overwritted again.

Change-Id: Ic002fef0875d98cec4f0779b4cd0b47849de1882
Closes-bug: #1512563
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/38/245038/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: instance.save(expected_task_state= (task_states.NETWORKING, task_states.SCHEDULING, None)) except exception.InstanceNotFound: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): # Make sure the async call finishes if network_info is not None: network_info.wait(do_raise=False) except exception.UnexpectedDeletingTaskStateError: instance.task_state = task_states.DELETING
deleted_lines: instance.save() except (exception.InstanceNotFound, exception.UnexpectedDeletingTaskStateError):

commit_message:
Don't reschedule if instance deleted.

On the compute node, if we want to do a retry we should check that
the instance.task_state matches one of the expected values.

In particular, there's no point in rescheduling an instance that
the user has requested be deleted.  (In which case the task_state
will be set to DELETING.)

Change-Id: I815a3eaf28c0fd508ae95884efeb0396a0af5475
Closes-Bug: #1542039
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/276783/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Check the task state. If someone has already deleted # the instance we don't want to reschedule it. instance.save( expected_task_state=[None, task_states.BLOCK_DEVICE_MAPPING, task_states.NETWORKING, task_states.SPAWNING])
deleted_lines: instance.save()

commit_message:
Add Console and ConsolePool objects

This change adds Console and ConsolePool objects to be used to replace
direct db calls in the console code.

Related to blueprint mitaka-objects

Change-Id: Id6555a8d076bc08cdaef958168c1669308a657a1

commit_message:
Add PciDevicePoolList.get_all method

This method executes subquery on pci_devices table and returns PciDevicePoolList containing all pci devices. It will be used by HostManager to get pci device info.

Add PciDevicePool _from_db_object method.

Change-Id: I9bec9f5f900a4f0f730b834aab4b71f21d68e686
Implements: blueprint pci-stats-generate

added_lines: def pci_device_pools_get_all(context): result = model_query(context, models.PciDevice, ( models.PciDevice.compute_node_id, models.PciDevice.product_id, models.PciDevice.vendor_id, models.PciDevice.numa_node, func.count(models.PciDevice.id) ), read_deleted="no").\ group_by( models.PciDevice.compute_node_id, models.PciDevice.product_id, models.PciDevice.vendor_id, models.PciDevice.numa_node ).all() if [(None, None, None, None, 0)] == result: result = [] fields = ('compute_node_id', 'product_id', 'vendor_id', 'numa_node', 'count') return [{field: pool_properties[idx] for idx, field in enumerate(fields)} for pool_properties in result] @main_context_manager.reader

subject: Fix order of arguments in assertEqual
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-09-01 13:12:21.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_flavor_swap.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_floating_ip_dns.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_flavor_rxtx.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_floating_ips_bulk.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_flavor_disabled.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_flavorextradata.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_floating_ips.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_flavor_access.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_floating_ip_pools.py', 'nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_flavors.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/df0e77d89fd5f4010b89f18c77082b7a61d6d17e', 'message': 'Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).

Partial-Bug: #1259292
Change-Id: I7e4e1130314bde16b384c53750f56312b1816c83
'}]
commit_message:
Fix order of arguments in assertEqual

Some tests used incorrect order assertEqual(observed, expected).

The correct order expected by testtools is
assertEqual(expected, observed).

Partial-Bug: #1259292
Change-Id: I7e4e1130314bde16b384c53750f56312b1816c83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/69/219269/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.assertEqual(expected, flavor) self.assertEqual(expected, flavor) self.assertEqual(expected_flavors, response_list) self.assertEqual('next', response_links[0]['rel']) self.assertEqual(expected_flavors, response_list) self.assertEqual('next', response_links[0]['rel']) self.assertEqual(expected_flavors, response_list) self.assertEqual('next', response_links[0]['rel']) self.assertEqual(expected, flavors) self.assertEqual(expected, flavor) self.assertEqual(expected, flavor) self.assertEqual(self.disabled_type['name'], flavor['name']) self.assertEqual(self.disabled_type['name'], flavor['name'])
deleted_lines: self.assertEqual(flavor, expected) self.assertEqual(flavor, expected) self.assertEqual(response_list, expected_flavors) self.assertEqual(response_links[0]['rel'], 'next') self.assertEqual(response_list, expected_flavors) self.assertEqual(response_links[0]['rel'], 'next') self.assertEqual(response_list, expected_flavors) self.assertEqual(response_links[0]['rel'], 'next') self.assertEqual(flavors, expected) self.assertEqual(flavor, expected) self.assertEqual(flavor, expected) self.assertEqual(flavor['name'], self.disabled_type['name']) self.assertEqual(flavor['name'], self.disabled_type['name'])

subject: Search for more keys when clearing passwords
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-20 19:51:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/52af9a210d2ff4fa0035cfc7f8c44f2f89c92793', 'message': "Search for more keys when clearing passwords

Originally, when cleansing dicts of passwords, it just searched through
the keys, eliminating all that contained '_pass'. This allowed secrets
such as admin_token and adminPass to get through. oslo_utils.strutils
has a set of keys that it searches for in strings when masking
passwords. This set of keys is copied over to nova, and now all keys
within this set (along with keys containing '_pass' to retain original
functionality) are also eliminated from dicts.

Change-Id: I4bfba1f54f8f9b5ce65c6677b8e58f1e0b09c403
Closes-Bug: #1487038

commit_message:
Search for more keys when clearing passwords

Originally, when cleansing dicts of passwords, it just searched through
the keys, eliminating all that contained '_pass'. This allowed secrets
such as admin_token and adminPass to get through. oslo_utils.strutils
has a set of keys that it searches for in strings when masking
passwords. This set of keys is copied over to nova, and now all keys
within this set (along with keys containing '_pass' to retain original
functionality) are also eliminated from dicts.

Change-Id: I4bfba1f54f8f9b5ce65c6677b8e58f1e0b09c403
Closes-Bug: #1487038

commit_message:
Set XenAPI-specific swap and ephemeral device_name

Implements a XenAPI-specific block device naming scheme in that
explicitly names swap and ephemeral block devices (and leverages the
default naming scheme for remaining block devices) that matches the
XenAPI device assignment scheme.

After a recent change block device mappings are explicitly added for a
flavor's swap and ephemeral devices, but the default block device
naming scheme did not match XenAPI's block device assignment scheme
and was therefor creating incorrect bdm entries that were consuming
unused devices names.

Change-Id: I2b3c4525428361ef91e145c9c393b25aa70fb3ed
Closes-Bug: 1482403

self.assertEqual('/dev/xvdb', self.block_device_mapping[1]['device_name']) self.assertEqual('/dev/xvdd', self.block_device_mapping[2]['device_name']) def test_all_together(self): # Test swap missing subject: Xenapi: Mount Configdrive with proper vbd type
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-30 08:44:38.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/xenapi/vm_utils.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/xenapi/test_vm_utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/73718be02aeeff8100f77bb5baf37632fd088240', 'message': "Xenapi: Mount Configdrive with proper vbd type

Currently within nova.virt.xenapi.vm_utils generate-configdrive
generates a VBD for the configdrive as vbd_type 'Disk', however the
data itself is created with an ISO9660(CDFS) filesystem.  This issue
does not currently cause any impact within *nix operating systems as
the disk recognition and mounting abilities seem quite lenient, however
this does cause issues within a Windows DomU.

When attached to a Windows DomU the disk is not recognized in any way
within the OS layer, whether this be through powershell or the standard
GUI methods (such as Disk Management).  Reading nova.conf to determine
the proper VBD type for the environment corrects this,  and is still
compatible with cloud-init configurations on both *nix and Windows.

This issue was addressed for libvirt within commit
'7f4b5771633f519a54aae985ae526418114b1a29' and as such I have made the
code look as similar as possible to maintain continuity.  This includes
the new method and tests to pull the Nova config drive type desired
from nova.conf.

Change-Id: I826f4280d63a34967ab37a2898a0a3db98d5285b
Closes-Bug: 1490238
"}]
commit_message:
Xenapi: Mount Configdrive with proper vbd type

Currently within nova.virt.xenapi.vm_utils generate-configdrive
generates a VBD for the configdrive as vbd_type 'Disk', however the
data itself is created with an ISO9660(CDFS) filesystem.  This issue
does not currently cause any impact within *nix operating systems as
the disk recognition and mounting abilities seem quite lenient, however
this does cause issues within a Windows DomU.

When attached to a Windows DomU the disk is not recognized in any way
within the OS layer, whether this be through powershell or the standard
GUI methods (such as Disk Management).  Reading nova.conf to determine
the proper VBD type for the environment corrects this,  and is still
compatible with cloud-init configurations on both *nix and Windows.

This issue was addressed for libvirt within commit
'7f4b5771633f519a54aae985ae526418114b1a29' and as such I have made the
code look as similar as possible to maintain continuity.  This includes
the new method and tests to pull the Nova config drive type desired
from nova.conf.

Change-Id: I826f4280d63a34967ab37a2898a0a3db98d5285b
Closes-Bug: 1490238

commit_message:
Use zuul-cloner for install-guide and api-* docs jobs

Use zuul-cloner with constraints set up for the project specific
install-guide and api-* docs jobs, so that projects can use constraints
and do not need a special install_command in their tox.ini for these.

Change-Id: I8f45a53429b9fcbf3689a268f096afdf5f32f461

commit_message:
Remove the old object_compat wrapper.

Simply obey the comment that this should be removed "after
icehouse". I think we've reached that point now.

I've also removed the object primative in get_instance_diagnostics.

Change-Id: I2d080813a585d785c704b47d75dca87194b34fbe

deleted_lines: # TODO(danms): Remove me after Icehouse # NOTE(mikal): if the method being decorated has more than one decorator, then # put this one first. Otherwise the various exception handling decorators do # not function correctly. def object_compat(function): """Wraps a method that expects a new-world instance This provides compatibility for callers passing old-style dict instances. """ @functools.wraps(function) def decorated_function(self, context, *args, **kwargs): def _load_instance(instance_or_dict): if isinstance(instance_or_dict, dict): # try to get metadata and system_metadata for most cases but # only attempt to load those if the db instance already has # those fields joined metas = [meta for meta in ('metadata', 'system_metadata') if meta in instance_or_dict] instance = objects.Instance._from_db_object( context, objects.Instance(), instance_or_dict, expected_attrs=metas) instance._context = context return instance return instance_or_dict try: kwargs['instance'] = _load_instance(kwargs['instance']) except KeyError: args = (_load_instance(args[0]),) + args[1:] migration = kwargs.get('migration') if isinstance(migration, dict): migration = objects.Migration._from_db_object( context.elevated(), objects.Migration(), migration) kwargs['migration'] = migration return function(self, context, *args, **kwargs) return decorated_function @object_compat @object_compat

commit_message:
Update the image size according to datastore

Some image types are converted while they are cached in the vSphere
datastore, which changes their size.  Therefore we can't rely on the
the size that Glance provides us in the meta data.  This fix
introduces another callback which updates the images size for image
types that are known to be converted.

This has been addressed in I18628fe3a180f722936c680c6be30d5ed4d50bd9
but that fix was incomplete, as it only handled sparse images.

Related-Bug: #1240373
Related-Bug: #1472955
Change-Id: I9ec344e25fef940b488ac7139fa0e7db882bea48

added_lines: # Copyright 2016 Intel # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import requests import requests_mock import testtools from syntribos.checks.fingerprint import remote_os from syntribos.checks.fingerprint import server_software class FakeInitSignals(object): def ran_check(self, check_name): pass class FakeTestObject(object): """A class to generate fake test objects.""" def __init__(self, resp): self.init_resp = resp self.init_req = resp.request self.test_resp = resp self.test_req = resp.request self.init_signals = FakeInitSignals() class TestFingerprint(testtools.TestCase): @requests_mock.Mocker() def test_server_software_found(self, m): headers = {"Server": "WSGIServer"} m.register_uri("GET", "http://example.com", headers=headers) resp = requests.get("http://example.com") test = FakeTestObject(resp) signal = server_software(test) self.assertEqual("SERVER_SOFTWARE_WSGI", signal.slug) @requests_mock.Mocker() def test_server_software_not_found(self, m): m.register_uri("GET", "http://example.com") resp = requests.get("http://example.com") test = FakeTestObject(resp) signal = server_software(test) self.assertEqual("SERVER_SOFTWARE_UNKNOWN", signal.slug) @requests_mock.Mocker() def test_remote_os_found(self, m): headers = {"X-Distribution": "Ubuntu"} m.register_uri("GET", "http://example.com", headers=headers) resp = requests.get("http://example.com") test = FakeTestObject(resp) signal = remote_os(test) self.assertEqual("SERVER_OS_UBUNTU", signal.slug) @requests_mock.Mocker() def test_remote_os_not_found(self, m): m.register_uri("GET", "http://example.com") resp = requests.get("http://example.com") test = FakeTestObject(resp) signal = remote_os(test) self.assertEqual("SERVER_OS_UNKNOWN", signal.slug)

commit_message:
Use bundletester for amulet test execution

Switch to using bundletester for execution of functional tests,
leveraging tox to build out test virtualenvs.

Rename amulet tests inline with gate-* and dfs-* naming standards.

Update README to refer to functional testing section of the charm
guide.

Change-Id: I60befab62843fa439a6a1fc897851091e4d47d49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-compute refs/changes/09/344109/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:func27-noop] # DRY RUN - For Debug basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "gate-*" -n --no-destroy [testenv:func27] # Charm Functional Test # Run all gate tests which are +x (expected to always pass) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "gate-*" --no-destroy [testenv:func27-smoke] # Charm Functional Test # Run a specific test as an Amulet smoke test (expected to always pass) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json gate-basic-xenial-mitaka --no-destroy [testenv:func27-dfs] # Charm Functional Test # Run all deploy-from-source tests which are +x (may not always pass!) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "dfs-*" --no-destroy [testenv:func27-dev] # Charm Functional Test # Run all development test targets which are +x (may not always pass!) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "dev-*" --no-destroy

commit_message:
Fix ceilometer auth url on undercloud

Due to a recent change introduced in puppet ceilometer[1]
ceilometer auth type defaults to password type and v2
auth_url doesnt work with domain. This fixes the url to
not include suffix.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/320454/

Change-Id: I6064d152cbfeebdc5ac1fd570daf91cd55097754
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/instack-undercloud refs/changes/79/344279/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Refuse to delete compute service if host is in host aggregate
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-01 16:25:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/b0b098c591e06ad8b37b655a846b5fb5cbde359f', 'message': 'Refuse to delete compute service if host is in host aggregate

User need to remove host from host aggregate, before removing the compute
service. Otherwise, host aggreate will deny to remove this host, because
compute service does not exist. And user will not able to delete this host
aggregate either, because it is not empty. This code change prevents user to
remove a compute service, before removing its host from host aggregate.

Change-Id: I8932737291d52c52b649a641dabe80fe443e028f
Closes-Bug: 1470341
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-02 09:39:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3a6dcc4c0041c3344f58e57b1cb096193e1da6a5', 'message': 'Refuse to delete compute service if host is in host aggregate

commit_message:
Refuse to delete compute service if host is in host aggregate

User need to remove host from host aggregate, before removing the compute
service. Otherwise, host aggreate will deny to remove this host, because
compute service does not exist. And user will not able to delete this host
aggregate either, because it is not empty. This code change prevents user to
remove a compute service, before removing its host from host aggregate.

Change-Id: I8932737291d52c52b649a641dabe80fe443e028f
Closes-Bug: 1470341

Otherwise, aggreate will deny to exclude this host, # if the compute service does not exist. if service.topic == 'compute': aggregates = objects.AggregateList.get_by_host(context, service.host) if aggregates: raise exception.ComputeServiceInAggregate( host=service.host, aggregate=aggregates[0].name) service.destroy()

commit_message:
Add support for using Ironic's node name as the hostname of the instance

This patch adds a new configuration option called "use_node_name_as_hostname"
in the [ironic] group which adds support for using the Ironic node's name
as the hostname for the instances being deployed by the Ironic driver.
This comes handy for people managing a lot of bare metal servers and
using the Ironic's name field to contain information about rack
location, rack number, node number etc...

Closes-Bug: #1508970
Change-Id: I1492edfe9c3bcb4daa6f447e0689ef2f5ff1cb37

commit_message:
Remove mox from tests/unit/objects/test_quotas.py

In test_commit_none_reservations and test_rollback_none_reservations, we
were previously not checking that the call wasn't made to
Quotas.commit() or Quotas.rollback() methods of objects/quotas.py.
Added an assert for the same now.

part of bp:remove-mox

Change-Id: I38f3ddb9fd394b5e717ab26727fa5847d5ca5a53

commit_message:
Correct MoveClaim in getting pci requests

Correct MoveClaim to get pci_requests from
`objects.InstancePCIRequests.get_by_instance_uuid_and_newness()`
according to the discussion in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/262939/3/nova/compute/claims.py L351

MoveClaim should use a same set of pci requests to claim numa topology
and pci devices. And _test_pci() can be refactored because MoveClaim is
changed to test pci in a consistent way with SchedulerClaim and
ComputeClaim.

This is a separate patch to refactor claim code because it needs to
change(correct) the claim behavior of compute service. The behavior
changes are tested in unit tests.

Change-Id: I57b783bae94a29b59ce80c8c60bf2820fd138d38
Related to blueprint host-state-level-locking

commit_message:
objects: Add multi sort keys impl into FlavorList

Add an function to separate the multi sort keys logic from
the single one.

commit_message:
Remove mox from simple test_instance.py tests

'Simple' means the tests which had only one method/function mocked out.

Part of bp: remove-mox

Change-Id: Ieb1bbd1dd118f6ab4da6a9cb3609f83b163ff3b5

commit_message:
Sync vms az with the host when using aggregate

The AZ for vms on one host should be the same as the host or none,
when using aggregate, the AZ of the host can be changed between the default
and the AZ of the aggregate, at this time, we should sysc the AZ for all the
vms on this host to be consistent.
For example, vm1 is booted with specified available zone AZ1, and it is scheduled
to host A, which is belonging to AZ1 too, then remove host A from AZ1 and add it to
AZ2 by using aggregate-remove-host and aggregate-add-host, at this time, available
zone for vm1 is AZ1, but the vm is located at a host belonging to AZ2, that is
conflict, and we should sync the az of the vm with the host.

Closes-Bug: #1444841
Change-Id: Ic220caab1a45f12a679e97929628b604487629a9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/226683/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: for host in aggregate.hosts: self._sync_instances_az_for_host(context, host, metadata.get('availability_zone')) def _sync_instances_az_for_host(self, context, host_name, az_name): instances = objects.InstanceList.get_by_host(context, host_name, expected_attrs=['availability_zone'], use_slave=True) for instance in instances: if instance.availability_zone and instance.availability_zone != az_name: instance.availability_zone = az_name instance.save() if aggregate.metadata.get('availability_zone'): self._sync_instances_az_for_host(context, host_name, aggregate.metadata.get('availability_zone')) if CONF.default_availability_zone: self._sync_instances_az_for_host(context, host_name, CONF.default_availability_zone)

compute_nodes.pci_stats field in the database. Added
get_by_compute_node method to PciDevicePoolList which get all the
pci devices owned by the node and group them into pci device pools.

This change will allow to get pci device data directly from db and
don't care about sync between internal objects storing pci data
and pci_device db table.

"}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2015-12-10 16:30:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/93755bded61daff343c8fdcc684bdf0c6d458b7e', 'message': "Add PciDevicePoolList.get_by_compute_node method

Modified the nova.objects.ComputeNode object to load on-demand the
pci_device_pools field by a subquery instead of pulling from the
compute_nodes.pci_stats field in the database. Added
get_by_compute_node method to PciDevicePoolList which get all the
pci devices owned by the node and group them into pci device pools.

Add pci_device_pools_get_by_node function to db api which gets pci
devices from pci_devices table belonging to given compute node and
organizes them into list containing dict representation of pci
device pools.

This change will allow to get pci device data directly from db and
don't care about sync between internal objects storing pci data
and pci_device db table.

Change-Id: I3825708e4ad966c4ba99c1d7df56e6e54eb653ed
Implements: blueprint pci-stats-generate

commit_message:
Deprecate ComputeNode pci_device_pools field

Deprecate ComputeNode pci_device_pools field starting from version 1.17.

Change-Id: I3825708e4ad966c4ba99c1d7df56e6e54eb653ed
Implements: blueprint pci-stats-generate
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/92/247692/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def pci_device_pools_get_by_node(context, node_id): result = model_query(context, models.PciDevice, ( models.PciDevice.product_id, models.PciDevice.vendor_id, models.PciDevice.numa_node, func.count(models.PciDevice.id) ), read_deleted="no").\ filter_by(compute_node_id=node_id).\ all() if [(None, None, None, 0)] == result: result = [] fields = ('product_id', 'vendor_id', 'numa_node', 'count') return [{field: pool_properties[idx] for idx, field in enumerate(fields)} for pool_properties in result] @main_context_manager.reader

commit_message:
Make use of new Console and ConsolePool objects

This change replace direct db calls in nova/console code with calls
that use the newly introduced Console and ConsolePools objects.

This includes:
* removing the unused db.console_get_by_pool_instance
* converting from [] to regular object attribute calls

Related to blueprint mitaka-objects

commit_message:
Update executor to eventlet

Default 'blocking' executor handles only one message at once.
'eventlet' executor is recommended.

Change-Id: Id738d0462fbb3c7fd6c78ee2f0dd0f1e79131ca7
Closes-Bug: #1517843

commit_message:
Make the server group invalid format message more verbose

The "Invalid format for name: '%s'" message returned when creating
a server group doesn't describe the rules for a valid name.
I changed the message to match the current regex for a valid
name.  I also did some refactoring so that the 2 modules
checking for valid names are calling a common function
to get the error message.  This will avoid returning an
old message if the regex changes.

Change-Id: Id61f1750f9ae31eecbc2edbd96e3533ea62eb20e
Closes-bug: 1431932

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: do not run upgrade on fresh install

This avoids creating the full table of the old Ceilometer alarms stuff on fresh
install, while upgrade will just ignore them.

Change-Id: I06f825d9a65da46fb7c30fd07c706ee018098b83

commit_message:
sqlalchemy: fix JSONEncodedDict implementation type

It's actually Text, not String, as correctly written in migration
scripts.

This fixes an error on MySQL as String is converted to VARCHAR which
requires a length.

Change-Id: I5f5d7902c647ba0b7a214bca21d0df1cc96fc57c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/24/333924/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: UniqueConstraint, BigInteger) impl = String

commit_message:
Update {configure|cleanup}ironic_provision_network.

Use OSC instead of Neutron client in configure_ironic_provision_network.
Do not rely on local.conf variable when perform cleaning in
cleanup_ironic_provision_network.

commit_message:
Add vercmp function

The existing vercmp_numbers function only handles, as the name says,
numbers.  I noticed that "sort" has had a version sort for a long time
[1] and, rather than re-implement it badly, use this as a version of
vercmp that works a bit more naturally.

This is intended to be used in an "if" statement as in

  prog_ver=$(prog_ver --version | grep ...)
  if vercmp $prog_ver "<" 2.0; then
     ...
  fi

A test-case is added to test the basic features and some edge-cases.

[1] http://git.savannah.gnu.org/gitweb/?p=coreutils.git;a=commitdiff;h=4c9fae4e97d95a9f89d1399a8aeb03051f0fec96

Conflicts:
	tests/unittest.sh

Change-Id: Ie55283acdc40a095b80b2631a55310072883ad0d
(cherry picked from commit 2ba36cda7940d630514a7864132837191d8c561f)

commit_message:
Introduce objects into sahara. This enables objects to be passed over RPC and
decouple the database implementation from SQLAlchemy.

Change-Id: If65d2d0e8cf5ddab9ca1cb5d004468614204480b
Implements: blueprint versioned-objects
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara-specs refs/changes/14/167114/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Sahara Versioned Objects ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/sahara/+spec/versioned-objects The goal of this spec is to introduce objects into Sahara. An object is used to bundle data with methods that can operate on them. By implementing this spec, we would be able to pass rich objects over RPC and decouple the database schema implementation from SQLAlchemy. Problem description =================== We are looking to improve the way we deal with versioning (of all sorts db/rpc/rest/templates/plugins). Nova has come up with the idea of versioned objects, that Ironic has also now used. This has now been proposed as an oslo library: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/ Versioned-objects will help us deal with DB schema being at a different version than the code expects. This will allow Sahara to be operated safely during upgrades. Proposed change =============== There is an approved proposal to put nova.objects into oslo as oslo.versionedobjects - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/ - which would abstract versionable internal objects for use with RPC. The plan is to adopt oslo.versionedobjects and abstract Sahara db models. The proposed changes are: * Create a directory sahara/objects/ that will contain wrapper objects that are a layer above the db objects. * Objects will be database schema independent. * Objects will be sent over RPC instead of ids, reducing the additional database hits to query the SQLAlchemy objects. * Objects will be versioned, allowing older objects to be detected and taking appropriate actions when the objects are incompatible, i.e. fail gracefully or emulate older behavior. * To handle cases where the underlying cluster, nodeGroup, instance could have been changed when the object is in flight, additional arguments (e.g. expected_cluster_state and expected_nodegroup_state) would be included in the object save method, which would check against the in-database copy of the icluster, nodeGroup, instance before updates are made and fail gracefully or appropriately sync up the data. Once the objects are in place the rest of the code will be changed to use the versioned objects instead of the db_api directly. This can be done object-by-object to avoid overly large changes. Alternatives ------------ Sahara could continue to be tightly tied to SQLAlchemy, limiting support to only SQL databases. Also, the existing implementation of sending ids over RPC can be left as-is. Data model impact ----------------- None. Sahara objects provides an abstraction layer in Sahara, allowing for database schema independence. These objects are a replacement for SQLAlchemy objects that are being used to represent db models throughout Sahara internals. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Unknown. There might be a minor hit in performance since SQLAlchemy objects are abstracted into Sahara objects. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Today, database APIs are called directly to create, read, update, and delete cluster, instance and others. With the switch to an object model, these calls will be made against the appropriate object methods. It will take some time to convert Sahara internals over to the object model, so the existing convention of direct database calls should be accepted until all object models are in place. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: yuntongjin Other contributors: Any help is welcome Work Items ---------- * Implement the objects for each DB object type we have. * Update code that uses the DB to use versioned-objects instead. * Write some developer docs on how to deal with older schema. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= By introducing objects, we are not changing the end user facing API or functionality of Sahara. We are passing objects over RPC instead of ids. Given this, no new tempest tests will be created. However, relevant unit tests will be created to test the new object code base. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * oslo-specs: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/127532/

Modify auto-compelete to reflect the new CLI

As opencafe has been removed and there are slight changes
in the way the new CLI works, auto-completion feature has
to be modified accordingly.

commit_message:
Remove unused columns parameters in watcher/db/api

In watcher/db/api.py, some abstract methods are specifying a 'columns'
parameter that is actually ignored in db/sqlalchemy/api.py. Since we
do not need this parameter, realignment was done for the signatures
of these methods, by removing the 'column' parameter (and its
docstring) from every single one of the following methods.

get_audit_template_list
get_audit_list
get_action_list
get_action_plan_list

Closes-Bug: #1597641
Change-Id: If706e24d5714f0139fd135bdc41d17d0e431e302
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/watcher refs/changes/92/336392/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def get_audit_template_list(self, context, filters=None, def get_audit_list(self, context, filters=None, limit=None, def get_action_list(self, context, filters=None, limit=None, self, context, filters=None, limit=None,
deleted_lines: :param columns: List of column names to return. Defaults to 'id' column when columns == None. def get_audit_template_list(self, context, columns=None, filters=None, :param columns: List of column names to return. Defaults to 'id' column when columns == None. def get_audit_list(self, context, columns=None, filters=None, limit=None, :param columns: List of column names to return. Defaults to 'id' column when columns == None. def get_action_list(self, context, columns=None, filters=None, limit=None, :param columns: List of column names to return. Defaults to 'id' column when columns == None. self, context, columns=None, filters=None, limit=None, :param columns: List of column names to return. Defaults to 'id' column when columns == None. @abc.abstractmethod def get_efficacy_indicator_list(self, context, filters=None, limit=None, marker=None, sort_key=None, sort_dir=None): """Get specific columns for matching efficacy indicators. Return a list of the specified columns for all efficacy indicators that match the specified filters. :param context: The security context :param columns: List of column names to return. Defaults to 'id' column when columns == None. :param filters: Filters to apply. Defaults to None. :param limit: Maximum number of efficacy indicators to return. :param marker: The last item of the previous page; we return the next result set. :param sort_key: Attribute by which results should be sorted. :param sort_dir: Direction in which results should be sorted. (asc, desc) :returns: A list of tuples of the specified columns. """ @abc.abstractmethod def create_efficacy_indicator(self, values): """Create a new efficacy indicator. :param values: A dict containing items used to identify and track the efficacy indicator. For example: :: { 'id': 1, 'uuid': utils.generate_uuid(), 'name': 'my_efficacy_indicator', 'display_name': 'My efficacy indicator', 'goal_uuid': utils.generate_uuid(), } :returns: An efficacy_indicator :raises: :py:class:`~.EfficacyIndicatorAlreadyExists` """ @abc.abstractmethod def get_efficacy_indicator_by_id(self, context, efficacy_indicator_id): """Return an efficacy indicator given its ID. :param context: The security context :param efficacy_indicator_id: The ID of an efficacy indicator :returns: An efficacy indicator :raises: :py:class:`~.EfficacyIndicatorNotFound` """ @abc.abstractmethod def get_efficacy_indicator_by_uuid(self, context, efficacy_indicator_uuid): """Return an efficacy indicator given its UUID. :param context: The security context :param efficacy_indicator_uuid: The UUID of an efficacy indicator :returns: An efficacy indicator :raises: :py:class:`~.EfficacyIndicatorNotFound` """ @abc.abstractmethod def get_efficacy_indicator_by_name(self, context, efficacy_indicator_name): """Return an efficacy indicator given its name. :param context: The security context :param efficacy_indicator_name: The name of an efficacy indicator :returns: An efficacy indicator :raises: :py:class:`~.EfficacyIndicatorNotFound` """ @abc.abstractmethod def destroy_efficacy_indicator(self, efficacy_indicator_uuid): """Destroy an efficacy indicator. :param efficacy_indicator_uuid: The UUID of an efficacy indicator :raises: :py:class:`~.EfficacyIndicatorNotFound` """ @abc.abstractmethod def update_efficacy_indicator(self, efficacy_indicator_uuid, values): """Update properties of an efficacy indicator. :param efficacy_indicator_uuid: The UUID of an efficacy indicator :returns: An efficacy indicator :raises: :py:class:`~.EfficacyIndicatorNotFound` :raises: :py:class:`~.Invalid` """

commit_message:
[doc] Update refarch router section

Update the refarch section to reflect what is now
happening within OVN to be consistent with the
other sections.

Change-Id: Ifabb728c03d59c306e81ba5e7179f1429a0264de

commit_message:
Switch HostState to use pci device pools

Change HostState to contain pci_device_pools attribute instead of
pci_stats. Pci passthrough and numa topology filters host_passes method
now checks pci device pools of the HostState instead of pci_stats.
Claim class was also changed to work with pci device pools while
claiming for pci devices.

This change will remove from us responsibility to look for sync between
pci devices in database and pci_stats view.

Change-Id: I5ef7cfb4ec05e677a136811a3a66d1fdaaaedf7b
Implements: blueprint pci-stats-generate

subject: Change HostManager to load pci_dev_pools from db
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-21 14:06:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/29f98bfe1e8f737b1821c8120211f2cff05615a9', 'message': 'Change HostManager to load pci_dev_pools from db

During initialization of HostState pci_device_pools set to None.
In update_from_compute_node method of HostState pci_device_pools no
longer updated from compute node.
During initialization of HostManager pci_device_pools for each compute
node is loaded from db using PciDevicePoolList.get_all() in case if
PciPassthroughFilter is enabled. Then for each host_state pci device
pools information is loaded from HostManager based on compute node id.

This fix will lead HostManager to use actual pci device pools data.

Change-Id: I259ee2a0031997ef63678a9a77b80ad11cd88360

commit_message:
Change HostManager to load pci_dev_pools from db

During initialization of HostState pci_device_pools is set to None.
In update_from_compute_node method of HostState pci_device_pools is no
longer updated from compute node.
During initialization of HostManager pci_device_pools for each compute
node is loaded from db using PciDevicePoolList.get_all() in case if
PciPassthroughFilter is enabled. Then for each host_state pci device
pools information is loaded from HostManager based on compute node id.

This fix will lead HostManager to use actual pci device pools data.

Change-Id: I259ee2a0031997ef63678a9a77b80ad11cd88360
Implements: blueprint pci-stats-generate
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/23/260023/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.pci_device_pools = None self._init_pci_device_pools() def _init_pci_device_pools(self): self.pci_device_pools = {} if 'PciPassthroughFilter' in [fltr.__class__.__name__ for fltr in self.default_filters]: elevated = context_module.get_admin_context() self.pci_device_pools =\ objects.PciDevicePoolList.get_all(elevated) host_state.pci_device_pools = self.pci_device_pools.get(compute.id)
deleted_lines: self.pci_device_pools = compute.pci_device_pools

commit_message:
WIP: Use state machines to manage the migraiton status field.

This patch adds a new status_machine field into class Migration.
This filed will be initialized when it is first used, and at this
time, "migration_type" and "status" fields should be initialized
first.

NOTE: The state machine has not been used in real migration code.
      And there is no test case for it. This is a WIP patch-set.

Change-Id: I77d7c0ec355204732d37d5b0211a3cc33185bbb8
Implements: blueprint migration-state-machine
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/80/241480/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def change_status(migration, event): if migration.status_machine is None: if migration.migration_type == 'live-migration': migration.status_machine = LiveMigrationStatusMachine.build( LiveMigrationStatusMachine.state_space) elif migration.migration_type == 'resize': migration.status_machine = ResizeStatusMachine.build( ResizeStatusMachine.state_space) elif migration.migration_type == 'evacuation': migration.status_machine = EvacuationStatusMachine.build( EvacuationStatusMachine.state_space) elif migration.migration_type == 'migration': migration.status_machine = MigrationStatusMachine.build( MigrationStatusMachine.state_space) migration.status_machine.initialize(migration.status) migration.status_machine.process_event(event) migration.status = migration.status_machine.current_state status_machine = None def status_change_notify(self, event): change_status(self, event)

WIP: db: Removes supported_instances from compute_node table

Column no longer necessary, as it is included in the host_capabilities
table.

Partially-Implements: blueprint expose-host-capabilities

commit_message:
WIP: drivers: Removes supported_instances from get_available_resource

Removes the mentioned field from the get_available_resource
returned data, as it is already reported as a host capability.

commit_message:
WIP: scheduler: removes check for supported_instances from filter

Removes checking the supported_instances from the
ImagePropsFilter.
Removes supported_instances from HostState.

commit_message:
scheduler: Adds HostCapabilitiesFilter filter

The mentioned filter will check the instance's image
metadata properties and flavor extra_specs for any
requested capabilities and checks whether the given
host is capable of satisfying the capabilities requested
by the instance.

Partially-Implements: blueprint expose-host-capabilities

Change-Id: Ia18f74bfdaee83f904d2d9653df79ce3397b1cac

commit_message:
API: Exposes host capabilities via the nova hypervisor API

Bumps nova API max microversion.
Adds 'host_capabilities' field to the result of the os-hypervisors/detail
and os-hypervisors/show nova APIs.
Adds API samples for the new microversion.
Adds unit and functional tests for the new microversion.

DocImpact

APIImpact

Change-Id: I06d4e5e9ba6398e6a4556a792fc4393ce940fa17
Partially-Implements: blueprint expose-host-capabilities

subject: Passing migrate_data to recover_method
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-04-07 17:43:34.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/ffe7c457ade2e2f819e461ea2254e2025cdec275', 'message': "shared block device will be deleted when live migration failed

In hyperv, xen and vmware, these api don't pass migrate_data to
live migration recover method. So if live migration failed, the
instance's image will be deleted in cleanup action if the instance
is using shared block device like ceph rbd.

Fixes bug: 1439609

Change-Id: If99af9f39eecbc44e9160fed564718715ffd8b84
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-15 07:49:23.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d5246bbd8a47e7d3949d74861e868d0f05f1c857', 'message': "shared block device will be deleted when live migration failed
