Change-Id: If99af9f39eecbc44e9160fed564718715ffd8b84
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-07-15 08:04:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f4337d881d91d11744c7be56af515e6a59d2adce', 'message': "shared block device will be deleted when live migration failed

In hyperv, xen and vmware, these api don't pass migrate_data to the
live migration recover method. So if live migration failed, the
instance's image will be deleted in cleanup action if the instance
is using shared block device like ceph rbd.

Fixes bug: 1439609

Change-Id: If99af9f39eecbc44e9160fed564718715ffd8b84
"}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2016-01-26 09:37:04.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/f1b54de5286712cf171248cf6d2f8d3e7fa2372d', 'message': "Passing migrate_data to recover_method

The method _rollback_live_migration() requires migrate_data to calculate
if it will do cleanup or destroy_disks.

In hyperv, xen and vmware, these api don't pass migrate_data to the
live migration recover method. So if live migration failed, the
instance's image will be deleted in cleanup action if the instance
is using shared block device like ceph rbd.

This patch also make migrate_data as required parameter in
_rollback_live_migration since all compute driver requires to pass it.

P.S. We can not just try to catch exception while driver do live_migration
since for libvirt driver it may call _rollback_live_migration itself
many times.

Closes-Bug: #1439609
Co-authored-by: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com>
Change-Id: If99af9f39eecbc44e9160fed564718715ffd8b84
"}, {'number': 5, 'created': '2016-01-28 01:17:25.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/virt/hyperv/test_livemigrationops.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/xenapi/test_xenapi.py', 'nova/virt/xenapi/vmops.py', 'nova/virt/hyperv/livemigrationops.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/19165e2d7f4afc86ffbaa386484e193775d92f3a', 'message': "Passing migrate_data to recover_method

The method _rollback_live_migration() requires migrate_data to calculate
if it will do cleanup or destroy_disks.

In hyperv and xen, these drivers don't pass migrate_data to the
live migration recover method. So if live migration failed, the
instance's image will be deleted in cleanup action if the instance
is using shared block device like ceph rbd.

This patch also make migrate_data as required parameter in
_rollback_live_migration since all compute driver requires to pass it.

P.S. We can not just try to catch exception while driver do live_migration
since for libvirt driver it may call _rollback_live_migration itself
many times.

Closes-Bug: #1439609
Co-authored-by: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com>
Change-Id: If99af9f39eecbc44e9160fed564718715ffd8b84
"}]
commit_message:
Passing migrate_data to recover_method

The method _rollback_live_migration() requires migrate_data to calculate
if it will do cleanup or destroy_disks.

In hyperv and xen, these drivers don't pass migrate_data to the
live migration recover method. So if live migration failed, the
instance's image will be deleted in cleanup action if the instance
is using shared block device like ceph rbd.

This patch also make migrate_data as required parameter in
_rollback_live_migration since all compute driver requires to pass it.

P.S. We can not just try to catch exception while driver do live_migration
since for libvirt driver it may call _rollback_live_migration itself
many times.

Closes-Bug: #1439609
Co-authored-by: Eli Qiao <liyong.qiao@intel.com>
Change-Id: If99af9f39eecbc44e9160fed564718715ffd8b84
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/10/171310/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: recover_method(context, instance_ref, dest, block_migration, migrate_data)
deleted_lines: recover_method(context, instance_ref, dest, block_migration)

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-20 22:06:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/874ed08f839148252b2e88f26cb84055969f0179', 'message': "Add external id on OVS port/interface for bridge lookup

You first have to query the list of ports on a bridge, then do a

name makes it possible to do a single 'find' query to get the

commit_message:
network: Add external id on OVS port/interface for bridge lookup

The OVS schema doesn't have references back to the bridge that a
port or interface is on. When trying to get a list of interface
details that are confined to a particular bridge, the ovs-vsctl
command does not allow this to be done in a single transaction.
You first have to query the list of ports on a bridge, then do a
separate transaction pulling the details of the Interfaces that
are attached to those ports. Adding an external_id with the bridge
name makes it possible to do a single 'find' query to get the
details of every interface tagged with that bridge name.

This should have no upgrade concerns for Nova and the lack of
these external_ids will have to be handled only on the Neutron
side.

A POC patch implementing the neutron side of this change is here:
  https://review.openstack.org/#/c/203381/

Change-Id: Ibc24aa47454774a540f8bff7d608509926cc1947
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/35/203835/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 'external-ids:vm-uuid=%s' % instance_id, 'external-ids:bridge-name=%s' % bridge, '--', 'set', 'Port', dev, 'external-ids:bridge-name=%s' % bridge])
deleted_lines: 'external-ids:vm-uuid=%s' % instance_id])

commit_message:
Change rgw frontend interface

Change the rgw frontend interface (from storage_interface to
api_interface) to make it consistent with the one specified in the
haproxy configuration.

commit_message:
Add LANG for puppet-cookiecutter

We're running into encoding issues as part of the puppet-cookiecutter
job so this is an attempt to see if the missing locale.conf can be
worked around in the job run until the image building process gets
fixed.

Change-Id: Ic89f34a7b2023aa00f464668cf68474f8fb52f68

commit_message:
add local.conf modifying functions

This adds a set of local.conf modifying functions which make it easier
for consuming projects like devstack-gate to programatically add
elements to local.conf structured files.

Change-Id: I3427968c2bd43aba12b3619acc27f73c74f0dabb
Co-Authored-By: fumihiko kakuma <kakuma@valinux.co.jp>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/72/326572/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Set a localrc var function localrc_set { local file=$1 local group="local" local conf="localrc" local section="" local option=$2 local value=$3 localconf_set "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section" "$option" "$value" } # Check if local.conf has section. function localconf_has_section { local file=$1 local group=$2 local conf=$3 local section=$4 local sep=$(echo -ne "\x01") local line line=$(sed -ne "\\${sep}^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]${sep},\\${sep}\[\[.*\]\]${sep}{ /\[${section}\]/p }" "$file") [ -n "$line" ] } # Check if local.conf has option. function localconf_has_option { local file=$1 local group=$2 local conf=$3 local section=$4 local option=$5 local sep=$(echo -ne "\x01") local line if [[ -z "$section" ]]; then line=$(sed -ne "\\${sep}^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]${sep},\\${sep}\[\[.*\]\]${sep}{ /${option}[ \t]*=.*$/p }" "$file") else line=$(sed -ne "\\${sep}^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]${sep},\\${sep}\[\[.*\]\]${sep}{ /\[${section}\]/,/\[\[.*\]\]\|\[.*\]/{ /${option}[ \t]*=.*$/p} }" "$file") fi [ -n "$line" ] } # Update option in local.conf. function localconf_update_option { local sudo=$1 local file=$2 local group=$3 local conf=$4 local section=$5 local option=$6 local value=$7 local sep=$(echo -ne "\x01") if [[ -z "$section" ]]; then $sudo sed -i -e "\\${sep}^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]${sep},\\${sep}\[\[.*\]\]${sep}{ s${sep}^\(${option}[ \t]*=[ \t]*\).*\$${sep}\1${value}${sep} }" "$file" else $sudo sed -i -e "\\${sep}^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]${sep},\\${sep}\[\[.*\]\]${sep}{ /\[${section}\]/,/\[\[.*\]\]\|\[.*\]/s${sep}^\(${option}[ \t]*=[ \t]*\).*\$${sep}\1${value}${sep} }" "$file" fi } # Add option in local.conf. function localconf_add_option { local sudo=$1 local file=$2 local group=$3 local conf=$4 local section=$5 local option=$6 local value=$7 local sep=$(echo -ne "\x01") if [[ -z "$section" ]]; then $sudo sed -i -e "\\${sep}^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]${sep} a $option = $value" "$file" else $sudo sed -i -e "\\${sep}^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]${sep},\\${sep}\[\[.*\]\]${sep}{ /\[${section}\]/ a $option = $value }" "$file" fi } # Add section and option in local.conf. function localconf_add_section_and_option { local sudo=$1 local file=$2 local group=$3 local conf=$4 local section=$5 local option=$6 local value=$7 local sep=$(echo -ne "\x01") $sudo sed -i -e "\\${sep}^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]${sep} { a [$section] a $option = $value }" "$file" } # Set an option in a local.conf file. # localconf_set [-sudo] config-file group conf-name section option value # - if the file does not exist, it is created function localconf_set { local xtrace=$(set +o | grep xtrace) set +o xtrace local sep=$(echo -ne "\x01") local sudo="" if [ $1 == "-sudo" ]; then sudo="sudo " shift fi local file=$1 local group=$2 local conf=$3 local section=$4 local option=$5 local value=$6 if [[ -z $group || -z $conf || -z $option || -z $value ]]; then $xtrace return fi if ! grep -q "^\[\[${group}|${conf}\]\]" "$file" 2>/dev/null; then # Add meta section at the end if it does not exist echo -e "\n[[${group}|${conf}]]" | $sudo tee --append "$file" > /dev/null # Add section at the end if [[ -n "$section" ]]; then echo -e "[$section]" | $sudo tee --append "$file" > /dev/null fi # Add option at the end echo -e "$option = $value" | $sudo tee --append "$file" > /dev/null elif [[ -z "$section" ]]; then if ! localconf_has_option "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section" "$option"; then # Add option localconf_add_option "$sudo" "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section" "$option" "$value" else # Replace it localconf_update_option "$sudo" "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section" "$option" "$value" fi elif ! localconf_has_section "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section"; then # Add section and option in specified meta section localconf_add_section_and_option "$sudo" "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section" "$option" "$value" elif ! localconf_has_option "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section" "$option"; then # Add option localconf_add_option "$sudo" "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section" "$option" "$value" else # Replace it localconf_update_option "$sudo" "$file" "$group" "$conf" "$section" "$option" "$value" fi $xtrace }

commit_message:
Following the hacking rule for string interpolation at logging

String interpolation should be delayed to be handled
by the logging code, rather than being done
at the point of the logging call.

See the oslo i18n guideline.

* http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html#adding-variables-to-log-messages

* http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.i18n/guidelines.html#avoid-forcing-the-translation-of-translatable-variables

commit_message:
Use freezegun to increment the clock in test_v3_filters

In preparation for making Fernet the default token provider, we must freeze and
increment the clock in certain tests. This is because Fernet does not support
sub-second precision and if a Fernet token is validated in the same second that
a revocation event has occured, it will be considered invalid.

This commit makes it so that we freeze the clock in
test_list_users_filtered_by_funny_name() and increment it by one second when we
go to list users by name.

This fix was originally a part of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/258650 but
this is an attempt to break 258650 into smaller, more reviewable, pieces.

Partial-Bug: 1561054
Change-Id: I3ea4af702e6914775156c605799992a41e8e75c5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/38/343738/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import datetime import freezegun # NOTE(lbragstad): Since Fernet tokens do not support sub-second # precision we must freeze the clock and ensure we increment the time # by a full second after a recovation event has occured. Otherwise the # token will be considered revoked even though it is actually a valid # token. time = datetime.datetime.utcnow() with freezegun.freeze_time(time) as frozen_datetime: self._set_policy({"identity:list_users": []}) user = self.user1 user['name'] = '%my%name%' self.identity_api.update_user(user['id'], user) frozen_datetime.tick(delta=datetime.timedelta(seconds=1)) url_by_name = '/users?name=%my%name%' r = self.get(url_by_name, auth=self.auth) self.assertEqual(1, len(r.result.get('users'))) self.assertEqual(user['id'], r.result.get('users')[0]['id'])
deleted_lines: self._set_policy({"identity:list_users": []}) user = self.user1 user['name'] = '%my%name%' self.identity_api.update_user(user['id'], user) url_by_name = '/users?name=%my%name%' r = self.get(url_by_name, auth=self.auth) self.assertEqual(1, len(r.result.get('users'))) self.assertEqual(user['id'], r.result.get('users')[0]['id'])

commit_message:
Add an ability to configure root_helper_daemon

To increase performance and don't call everytime
sudo it's possible to enable rootwrap demon to 'proxy' sudo calls.

Change-Id: Ie7765cd4aa41f95eb498a4132c38937b2817f8e8

commit_message:
Fix OVS agent parameters

Currently we have ovsdb_interface parameter which has docs and
validation for of_interface, but they are two different parameters.

Also added tests and updated acceptance spec.

Related-bug: #1599113

Change-Id: I1caa790d4e4aba614e49ba52138f78407bbb69c0

commit_message:
Nova: Set up cell0 database and cell mapping.

Set up the cell0 database and enter it in to the cell
mapping table.

cell0 is a required database for cellsV2 and holds all
of the instances that cannot be scheduled to a cell.

Change-Id: Ib574d2501193339f636eb640cda0b43aa3f21514
Depends-On: Ia000e970d66d75374fd7e4e8b9137e0c10939c8e
Depends-On: I21ae13a6c029e8ac89484faa212434911160fd51

added_lines: NOVA_CELL0_DB=${NOVA_CELL0_DB:-nova_cell0} # Add cell0 to the mapping table. $NOVA_BIN_DIR/nova-manage cell_v2 map_cell0 --database_connection=`database_connection_url $NOVA_CELL0_DB` # (Re)Create and sync cell0 database recreate_database $NOVA_CELL0_DB $NOVA_BIN_DIR/nova-manage db sync --cell_uuid='00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000'

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-19 04:48:51.000000000', 'files': ['doc/source/devref/quota.rst', 'neutron/quota/resource.py', 'neutron/db/quota/driver.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/c46edbc7d62585b0181dfe4bb72c1be0620fc937', 'message': "Use db_api.retry_db_errors in quota engine

The quota engine was still using oslo_db wrap_db_retry
which does not automatically take into account deadlocks
that occur inside of nested savepoint transactions.

In one case it didn't matter because it passed in the correct
exception checker but in the one that protected 'set_quota_usage'
it did not use is_retriable so a deadlock inside of the savepoint
would have resulted in a much more expensive retry all of the way
up at the API layer.

This patch just adjusts them to both use the standard neutron
retry_db_errors decorator.

Change-Id: I1e45eb15f14bf35881e5b1dce77733e831e9c6b1
Related-Bug: #1596075
"}]
commit_message:
Use db_api.retry_db_errors in quota engine

The quota engine was still using oslo_db wrap_db_retry
which does not automatically take into account deadlocks
that occur inside of nested savepoint transactions.

In one case it didn't matter because it passed in the correct
exception checker but in the one that protected 'set_quota_usage'
it did not use is_retriable so a deadlock inside of the savepoint
would have resulted in a much more expensive retry all of the way
up at the API layer.

This patch just adjusts them to both use the standard neutron
retry_db_errors decorator.

Change-Id: I1e45eb15f14bf35881e5b1dce77733e831e9c6b1
Related-Bug: #1596075
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/13/344013/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @db_api.retry_db_errors
deleted_lines: from oslo_db import api as oslo_db_api @oslo_db_api.wrap_db_retry(max_retries=db_api.MAX_RETRIES, retry_interval=0.1, inc_retry_interval=True, retry_on_request=True, exception_checker=db_api.is_retriable)

commit_message:
puppet-openstack-cookiecutter: run bash script for testing

Instead of defining in JJB the bash commands we want to run, just
execute a bash script so it will let us manage what we want to test
directly in the repository.

Change-Id: I2deee794e657b3a30e33dcfeb9563a87fe10ded5

deleted_lines: - gerrit-git-prep mkdir .bundled_gems export PUPPET_GEM_VERSION='~> {puppet_version}' export GEM_HOME=`pwd`/.bundled_gems gem install bundler --no-rdoc --no-ri --verbose OS_NEW_MODULE_TEST=yes bash -x ./contrib/bootstrap.sh whazz dummy cd puppet-whazz/puppet-modulesync-configs/modules/puppet-whazz $GEM_HOME/bin/bundle install --retry 3 $GEM_HOME/bin/bundle exec rake lint $GEM_HOME/bin/bundle exec rake validate $GEM_HOME/bin/bundle exec rake spec

commit_message:
Handle SSL termination proxies for version list

Cinder list with pagination contains wrong scheme for
'next' link in case of SSL endpoints. This patch fixes
it and returns the correct scheme in version URLs if
service is behind an SSL termination proxy.

Change-Id: If5aab9cc25a2e7c66a0bb13b5f7488a667b30309
Closes-Bug: #1558683
(cherry picked from commit d7e7e7bdf0f112c8315ae38f04b4849338173d51)

commit_message:
Add 'test' extra-require to setup.py

For a purpose of testing external extension I need to install nailgun as
a library, but with extra testing requirements. This patch adds
`extras_require` section to setup.py with test dependencies.

Change-Id: I3c1836da184e410d4bfa32ca854d80356f62968b
(cherry picked from commit 9e601d5edb5c464f1154cfb6c70ab6e7c0a84a73)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-web refs/changes/89/343589/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def find_requires(testing=False): if testing: filename = 'test-requirements.txt' else: filename = 'requirements.txt' with open(os.path.join(dir_path, filename), 'r') as reqs: for line in (l.strip() for l in reqs): if not line or line[0] in ('#', '-'): continue requirements.append(line) extras_require={ 'test': find_requires(testing=True), },

commit_message:
Check deprecation status for cells.py

Remove deprecated opt 'manager' as it is shown as one of the
options to be deprecated in Mitaka per document below:
 http://docs.openstack.org/mitaka/config-reference/tables/conf-changes/nova.html.

Blueprint centralize-config-options-newton

Change-Id: I6e3690c8905e052a6bc9910511c2596b5848acb4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/65/342365/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: # needs:check_deprecation_status cfg.StrOpt('manager', default='nova.cells.manager.CellsManager', deprecated_for_removal=True, help=""" DEPRECATED: Manager for cells The nova-cells manager class. This class defines RPC methods that the local cell may call. This class is NOT used for messages coming from other cells. That communication is driver-specific. Communication to other cells happens via the nova.cells.messaging module. The MessageRunner from that module will handle routing the message to the correct cell via the communication driver. Most methods below create 'targeted' (where we want to route a message to a specific cell) or 'broadcast' (where we want a message to go to multiple cells) messages. Scheduling requests get passed to the scheduler class. Possible values: * 'nova.cells.manager.CellsManager' is the only possible value for this option as of the Mitaka release """),

commit_message:
Storwize: Fix exception ProcessExecutionError

There is specific code in storwize_svc_common
get_host_from_connector to check for CMMVC5754E in
the exception coming back from lshost(), but the exception
type was ProcessExecutionError. I believe that was correct
at one point in the past, but it has been switched to be
exception.VolumeBackendAPIException now so this change looks
for that. Adds UT and other minor cleanup.

Change-Id: If3220e88ae191ca3b5ff0949212e2f23552de300
Closes-Bug: #1578294

commit_message:
Add missing LOG variable to fix scenario tests

When https://review.openstack.org/#/c/307346/ was rebased
with https:/review.openstack.org/#/c/309682, the LOG variable
was inadvertently removed. This commit adds it back as the
missing variable is causing a failure in the scenario tests.

Closes-Bug: 1604131

commit_message:
Reduce the OSIC max-servers

The OSIC cloud1 environment is currently running out of IPv4 space.
We are working on getting more IPv4 addresses and potentially
adding IPv6 however that will take a bit more time. Reducing this
value will ensure we're not seeing so many errors in the OSIC
as nodepool allocates resources for the gate.

Change-Id: I9c5eb20d965010c140880b1b309871fad57d8782
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Revert "Release xstatic-mdi 1.6.50.1"

The process for releasing xstatic packages appears to be broken
currently (see https://pypi.python.org/pypi/XStatic-mdi) so we
should revert the commit until the process can be fixed.

This reverts commit b18ad556f173d99d3703c71fdd2e08b9e28b2815.

Change-Id: I3b3db55e90d789c1fb044cd30d8c418f797ec5b4

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-03 03:24:48.000000000', 'files': ['nova/cells/scheduler.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/da0e9a9b315f720bf05a550182ef454a7ba27357', 'message': "Add correct form 'pci_requests' objects in build instance request on child cell.

In function of _create_instances_here in nova/cell/scheduler.py, 'pci_requests' is discarded directly. Because the instance was
brutally serialized before being sent over RPC to child cell. Thus, the pci_requests value wasn't really sent in a useful form.

Fixes Bug1540764.

Change-Id: Ibf1a3e126804e0a49f4bf397a847ea563cce9d30
"}]
commit_message:
Add correct form 'pci_requests' objects in build instance request on child cell.

In function of _create_instances_here in nova/cell/scheduler.py, 'pci_requests' is discarded directly. Because the instance was
brutally serialized before being sent over RPC to child cell. Thus, the pci_requests value wasn't really sent in a useful form.
So in Kilo an Liberty, 'pci_requests' is discarded directly.

Fixes Bug1540764.

Change-Id: Ibf1a3e126804e0a49f4bf397a847ea563cce9d30

stats.

subject: Add TriggerOnCall fixture
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-08-24 18:36:06.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/fixtures.py', 'nova/tests/unit/test_fixtures.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d7fc9d5b7f4781597047ae91e8797ff76fe41f01', 'message': 'Add TriggerOnCall fixture

This adds a fixture that lets you mock/wrap a method and block until it
is called. This could be useful for functional tests where we kick off
an operation in another greenthread and wait for it to finish. Currently,
we do things like poll in a (pretty) tight loop, which wastes CPU

Change-Id: I0a8dbf73c01939bcdf9b43c8f8b954a78b03794e

commit_message:
Add TriggerOnCall fixture

This adds a fixture that lets you mock/wrap a method and block until it
is called. This could be useful for functional tests where we kick off
an operation in another greenthread and wait for it to finish. Currently,
we do things like poll in a (pretty) tight loop, which wastes CPU
resources. This gives us a contextually-relevant wakeup to do our poll.

Change-Id: I0a8dbf73c01939bcdf9b43c8f8b954a78b03794e

added_lines: class TestTriggerOnCall(testtools.TestCase): def test_works(self): fixture = fixtures.TriggerOnCall('nova.utils.novadir') self.useFixture(fixture) self.assertFalse(fixture.ready()) self.assertIn('nova', utils.novadir()) self.assertTrue(fixture.ready()) def test_passes_exception(self): fixture = fixtures.TriggerOnCall('nova.utils.generate_uid') self.useFixture(fixture) self.assertRaises(TypeError, utils.generate_uid, 'foo', size='nan') self.assertTrue(fixture.ready()) def test_wait_gets_args(self): fixture = fixtures.TriggerOnCall('nova.utils.generate_uid') self.useFixture(fixture) utils.generate_uid('foo') utils.generate_uid('bar') self.assertEqual((('foo',), {}), fixture.wait()) self.assertEqual((('bar',), {}), fixture.wait()) def test_recallable(self): fixture = fixtures.TriggerOnCall('nova.utils.novadir') self.useFixture(fixture) self.assertFalse(fixture.ready()) self.assertIn('nova', utils.novadir()) self.assertTrue(fixture.ready()) fixture.wait() self.assertFalse(fixture.ready()) utils.novadir() self.assertTrue(fixture.ready()) fixture.wait() self.assertFalse(fixture.ready())

commit_message:
VMware: Refactor fetching all kinds of images

Currently we use callbacks to prepare/fetch/cache image in VMware,
It is a bit difficult to understand(to me). To make it more structured
and improve the maintainability of the code, let's use class & abstract
methods instead. And the code will be more clean.

How to do it:
1. Add a base class Image;
2. Add abstract methods for class Image:
    * def _prepare_image()
    * def _cache_image()
    * def _fetch_image()
    * def use_image()
    * ...
3. Add subclasses of class Image:
    * class FlatImage
    * class IsoImage
    * class SparseImage
    * class StreamOptimizedImage
    * class OvaImage
   Then let each class implements the abstract method mentioned above.

Change-Id: I1a4774c79162c7ca2b09f3386aefa65c01926842

added_lines: import collectionsfrom oslo_concurrency import lockutilsfrom oslo_utils import strutils, excutilsfrom oslo_utils import uuidutilsfrom nova.i18n import _, _LE, _LI, _LWfrom nova.virt.vmwareapi import ds_utilfrom oslo_vmware import exceptions as vexc from oslo_vmware import rw_handles from oslo_vmware import vim_util as vutil from oslo_vmware.objects import datastore as ds_obj class UploadImageTarget(object): """Target info of image to be uploaded to the VMWare datastore""" def __init__(self, host, port, dc_name, ds_name, file_path=None, vm_name=None, vm_folder_ref=None, res_pool_ref=None, cookies=None): self.host = host self.port = port self.dc_name = dc_name self.ds_name = ds_name self.file_path = file_path self.vm_name = vm_name self.vm_folder_ref = vm_folder_ref self.res_pool_ref = res_pool_ref self.cookies = cookies class VMwareImage(object): class Image(VMwareImage): """Image is the base image class of VMWare""" def __init__(self, **kwargs): self._session = kwargs.pop('session') self._volumeops = kwargs.pop('volumeops') self._tmp_folder = kwargs.pop('tmp_folder') self._get_ds_browser = kwargs.pop('get_ds_browser') self._check_cache_folder = kwargs.pop('check_cache_folder') super(Image, self).__init__(**kwargs) def fetch_image_if_missing(self, context, instance, vi): LOG.debug("Processing image %s", vi.ii.image_id, instance=instance) with lockutils.lock(str(vi.cache_image_path), lock_file_prefix='nova-vmware-fetch_image'): self.check_cache_folder(vi.datastore.name, vi.datastore.ref) ds_browser = self._get_ds_browser(vi.datastore.ref) if not ds_util.file_exists(self._session, ds_browser, vi.cache_image_folder, vi.cache_image_path.basename): LOG.debug("Preparing fetch location", instance=vi.instance) tmp_dir_loc, tmp_image_ds_loc = self._prepare_image(vi) LOG.debug("Fetch image to %s", tmp_image_ds_loc, instance=vi.instance) self._fetch_image(context, instance, vi, tmp_image_ds_loc) LOG.debug("Caching image", instance=vi.instance) self._cache_image(vi, tmp_image_ds_loc) LOG.debug("Cleaning up location %s", str(tmp_dir_loc), instance=vi.instance) self._delete_datastore_file(str(tmp_dir_loc), vi.dc_info.ref) def use_image(self, instance, vm_ref, vi): if self.linked_clone: self._use_disk_image_as_linked_clone(vm_ref, vi) else: self._use_disk_image_as_full_clone(vm_ref, vi) def _prepare_image(self, vi): pass def _cache_image(self, vi, tmp_image_ds_loc): pass def _post_fetch_image(self, context, instance, target, write_handle=None, write_handle=None): pass def _fetch_image(self, context, instance, vi, image_ds_loc, res_pool_ref=None): """Download image as an individual file to host via HTTP PUT.""" session = self._session LOG.debug("Downloading image file data %(image_id)s to " "%(file_path)s on the data store " "%(datastore_name)s", {'image_id': vi.ii.image_id, 'file_path': image_ds_loc, 'datastore_name': vi.datastore.name}, instance=instance) # try to get esx cookie to upload try: dc_name = 'ha-datacenter' host, cookies = self._get_esx_host_and_cookies( vi.datastore, dc_name, image_ds_loc.rel_path) except Exception as e: LOG.warning(_LW("Get esx cookies failed: %s"), e) dc_name = vi.dc_info.name host = self._session._host cookies = session.vim.client.options.transport.cookiejar target = UploadImageTarget(host=host, port=session._port, dc_name=dc_name, ds_name=vi.datastore.name, file_path=image_ds_loc.rel_path, vm_name=image_ds_loc.parent.basename, vm_folder_ref=vi.dc_info.vmFolder, res_pool_ref=res_pool_ref, cookies=cookies) image_size = self._do_fetch_image(context, instance, target) # The size of the image is different from the size of the virtual disk. # We want to use the latter. On vSAN this is the only way to get this # size because there is no VMDK descriptor. vi.ii.file_size = image_size def _do_fetch_image(self, context, instance, target): """Download image from glance, and upload it to VMWare datastore.""" image_ref = instance.image_ref ds_name = target.ds_name file_path = target.file_path LOG.debug("Downloading image file data %(image_ref)s to the " "data store %(data_store_name)s", {'image_ref': image_ref, 'data_store_name': ds_name}, instance=instance) read_handle = self._get_download_handle(context, image_ref) write_handle, file_size = self._get_upload_handle( context, image_ref, target) start_transfer(context, read_file_handle=read_handle, file_size=file_size, write_file_handle=write_handle) LOG.debug("Downloaded image file data %(image_ref)s to " "%(upload_name)s on the data store " "%(data_store_name)s", {'image_ref': image_ref, 'upload_name': 'n/a' if file_path is None else file_path, 'data_store_name': 'n/a' if ds_name is None else ds_name}, instance=instance) return self._post_fetch_image(context, instance, target, read_handle=read_handle, write_handle=write_handle) def _get_download_handle(self, context, image_ref): """Get handle of downloading image from the glance image server.""" read_iter = IMAGE_API.download(context, image_ref) read_file_handle = rw_handles.ImageReadHandle(read_iter) return read_file_handle def _get_upload_handle(self, context, image_ref, target): """Get handle of uploading image to the VMWare datastore.""" metadata = IMAGE_API.get(context, image_ref) file_size = int(metadata['size']) write_file_handle = rw_handles.FileWriteHandle( target.host, target.port, target.dc_name, target.ds_name, target.cookies, target.file_path, file_size) return write_file_handle, file_size @staticmethod def _move_to_cache(session, dc_ref, src_ds_path, dst_ds_path): try: ds_util.file_move(session, dc_ref, src_ds_path, dst_ds_path) except vexc.FileAlreadyExistsException: # Folder move has failed. This may be due to the fact that a # process or thread has already completed the operation. # Since image caching is synchronized, this can only happen # due to action external to the process. # In the event of a FileAlreadyExists we continue, # all other exceptions will be raised. LOG.warning(_LW("Destination %s already exists! Concurrent moves " "can lead to unexpected results."), dst_ds_path) @staticmethod def _delete_datastore_file(session, datastore_path, dc_ref): try: ds_util.file_delete(session, datastore_path, dc_ref) except (vexc.CannotDeleteFileException, vexc.FileFaultException, vexc.FileLockedException, vexc.FileNotFoundException): LOG.debug("Unable to delete %(ds)s. There may be more than " "one process or thread trying to delete the file", {'ds': datastore_path}, exc_info=True) @staticmethod def _extend_virtual_disk(session, instance, requested_size, name, dc_ref): service_content = session.vim.service_content LOG.debug("Extending root virtual disk to %s", requested_size, instance=instance) vmdk_extend_task = session._call_method( session.vim, "ExtendVirtualDisk_Task", service_content.virtualDiskManager, name=name, datacenter=dc_ref, newCapacityKb=requested_size, eagerZero=False) try: session._wait_for_task(vmdk_extend_task) except Exception as e: with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.error(_LE('Extending virtual disk failed with error: %s'), e, instance=instance) # Clean up files created during the extend operation files = [name.replace(".vmdk", "-flat.vmdk"), name] for file in files: ds_path = ds_obj.DatastorePath.parse(file) Image._delete_datastore_file(session, ds_path, dc_ref) LOG.debug("Extended root virtual disk", instance=instance) @staticmethod def _extend_if_required(session, dc_info, image_info, instance, root_vmdk_path): """Increase the size of the root vmdk if necessary.""" if instance.root_gb * units.Gi > image_info.file_size: size_in_kb = instance.root_gb * units.Mi Image._extend_virtual_disk(session, instance, size_in_kb, root_vmdk_path, dc_info.ref) def _get_esx_host_and_cookies(self, datastore, dc_name, file_path): hosts = datastore.get_connected_hosts(self._session) host = ds_obj.Datastore.choose_host(hosts) host_name = self._session._call_method(vutil, 'get_object_property', host, 'name') url = ds_obj.DatastoreURL('https', host_name, file_path, dc_name, datastore.name) cookie_header = url.get_transfer_ticket(self._session, 'PUT') name, value = cookie_header.split('=') # TODO(rgerganov): this is a hack to emulate cookiejar until we fix # oslo.vmware to accept plain http headers Cookie = collections.namedtuple('Cookie', ['name', 'value']) return host_name, [Cookie(name, value)] def _sized_image_exists(self, sized_disk_ds_loc, ds_ref): ds_browser = self._get_ds_browser(ds_ref) return ds_util.file_exists( self._session, ds_browser, sized_disk_ds_loc.parent, sized_disk_ds_loc.basename) def _use_disk_image_as_linked_clone(self, vm_ref, vi): """Uses cached image as parent of a COW child in the VM directory.""" sized_image_disk_name = "%s.vmdk" % vi.ii.image_id if vi.root_gb > 0: sized_image_disk_name = "%s.%s.vmdk" % (vi.ii.image_id, vi.root_gb) sized_disk_ds_loc = vi.cache_image_folder.join(sized_image_disk_name) # Ensure only a single thread extends the image at once. # We do this by taking a lock on the name of the extended # image. This allows multiple threads to create resized # copies simultaneously, as long as they are different # sizes. Threads attempting to create the same resized copy # will be serialized, with only the first actually creating # the copy. # # Note that the object is in a per-nova cache directory, # so inter-nova locking is not a concern. Consequently we # can safely use simple thread locks. with lockutils.lock(str(sized_disk_ds_loc), lock_file_prefix='nova-vmware-image'): if not self._sized_image_exists(sized_disk_ds_loc, vi.datastore.ref): LOG.debug("Copying root disk of size %sGb", vi.root_gb, instance=vi.instance) try: vm_util.copy_virtual_disk( self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, str(vi.cache_image_path), str(sized_disk_ds_loc)) except Exception as e: LOG.warning(_LW("Root disk file creation " "failed - %s"), e) with excutils.save_and_reraise_exception(): LOG.error(_LE('Failed to copy cached ' 'image %(source)s to ' '%(dest)s for resize: ' '%(error)s'), {'source': vi.cache_image_path, 'dest': sized_disk_ds_loc, 'error': e}) try: ds_util.file_delete(self._session, sized_disk_ds_loc, vi.dc_info.ref) except vexc.FileNotFoundException: # File was never created: cleanup not # required pass # Resize the copy to the appropriate size. No need # for cleanup up here, as _extend_virtual_disk # already does it self._extend_if_required(self._session, vi.dc_info, vi.ii, vi.instance, str(sized_disk_ds_loc)) # Associate the sized image disk to the VM by attaching to the VM a # COW child of said disk. self._volumeops.attach_disk_to_vm( vm_ref, vi.instance, vi.ii.adapter_type, vi.ii.disk_type, str(sized_disk_ds_loc), vi.root_gb * units.Mi, vi.ii.linked_clone, disk_io_limits=vi._extra_specs.disk_io_limits) def _use_disk_image_as_full_clone(self, vm_ref, vi): """Uses cached image disk by copying it into the VM directory.""" instance_folder = vi.instance.uuid root_disk_name = "%s.vmdk" % vi.instance.uuid root_disk_ds_loc = vi.datastore.build_path(instance_folder, root_disk_name) vm_util.copy_virtual_disk( self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, str(vi.cache_image_path), str(root_disk_ds_loc)) self._extend_if_required(self._session, vi.dc_info, vi.ii, vi.instance, str(root_disk_ds_loc)) self._volumeops.attach_disk_to_vm( vm_ref, vi.instance, vi.ii.adapter_type, vi.ii.disk_type, str(root_disk_ds_loc), vi.root_gb * units.Mi, False, disk_io_limits=vi._extra_specs.disk_io_limits) class IsoImage(Image): def _prepare_image(self, vi): tmp_dir_loc = vi.datastore.build_path( self._tmp_folder, uuidutils.generate_uuid()) tmp_image_ds_loc = tmp_dir_loc.join( vi.ii.image_id, vi.cache_image_path.basename) return tmp_dir_loc, tmp_image_ds_loc def _cache_image(self, vi, tmp_image_ds_loc): self._move_to_cache(self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, tmp_image_ds_loc.parent, vi.cache_image_folder) def use_image(self, instance, vm_ref, vi): """Uses cached image as a bootable virtual cdrom.""" self._attach_cdrom_to_vm(self._session, vm_ref, instance, vi.datastore.ref, str(vi.cache_image_path)) # Optionally create and attach blank disk if vi.root_gb > 0: instance_folder = vi.instance.uuid root_disk_name = "%s.vmdk" % vi.instance.uuid root_disk_ds_loc = vi.datastore.build_path(instance_folder, root_disk_name) # It is pointless to COW a blank disk linked_clone = False vm_util.create_virtual_disk( self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, vi.ii.adapter_type, vi.ii.disk_type, str(root_disk_ds_loc), vi.root_gb * units.Mi) self._volumeops.attach_disk_to_vm( vm_ref, vi.instance, vi.ii.adapter_type, vi.ii.disk_type, str(root_disk_ds_loc), vi.root_gb * units.Mi, linked_clone, disk_io_limits=vi._extra_specs.disk_io_limits) @staticmethod def _attach_cdrom_to_vm(session, vm_ref, instance, datastore, file_path): """Attach cdrom to VM by reconfiguration.""" client_factory = session.vim.client.factory devices = session._call_method(vutil, "get_object_property", vm_ref, "config.hardware.device") (controller_key, unit_number, controller_spec) = vm_util.allocate_controller_key_and_unit_number( client_factory, devices, constants.ADAPTER_TYPE_IDE) cdrom_attach_config_spec = vm_util.get_cdrom_attach_config_spec( client_factory, datastore, file_path, controller_key, unit_number) if controller_spec: cdrom_attach_config_spec.deviceChange.append(controller_spec) LOG.debug("Reconfiguring VM instance to attach cdrom %s", file_path, instance=instance) vm_util.reconfigure_vm(session, vm_ref, cdrom_attach_config_spec) LOG.debug("Reconfigured VM instance to attach cdrom %s", file_path, instance=instance) class FlatImage(Image): def _prepare_image(self, vi): tmp_dir_loc = vi.datastore.build_path( self._tmp_folder, uuidutils.generate_uuid()) tmp_image_ds_loc = tmp_dir_loc.join( vi.ii.image_id, vi.cache_image_path.basename) ds_util.mkdir(self._session, tmp_image_ds_loc.parent, vi.dc_info.ref) vm_util.create_virtual_disk( self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, vi.ii.adapter_type, vi.ii.disk_type, str(tmp_image_ds_loc), vi.ii.file_size_in_kb) flat_vmdk_name = vi.cache_image_path.basename.replace('.vmdk', '-flat.vmdk') flat_vmdk_ds_loc = tmp_dir_loc.join(vi.ii.image_id, flat_vmdk_name) self._delete_datastore_file(self._session, str(flat_vmdk_ds_loc), vi.dc_info.ref) return tmp_dir_loc, flat_vmdk_ds_loc def _cache_image(self, vi, tmp_image_ds_loc): self._move_to_cache(self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, tmp_image_ds_loc.parent, vi.cache_image_folder) class SparseImage(Image): def _prepare_image(self, vi): tmp_dir_loc = vi.datastore.build_path( self._tmp_folder, uuidutils.generate_uuid()) tmp_image_ds_loc = tmp_dir_loc.join( vi.ii.image_id, "tmp-sparse.vmdk") return tmp_dir_loc, tmp_image_ds_loc def _cache_image(self, vi, tmp_image_ds_loc): tmp_dir_loc = tmp_image_ds_loc.parent.parent converted_image_ds_loc = tmp_dir_loc.join( vi.ii.image_id, vi.cache_image_path.basename) # converts fetched image to preallocated disk vm_util.copy_virtual_disk( self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, str(tmp_image_ds_loc), str(converted_image_ds_loc)) self._delete_datastore_file(self._session, str(tmp_image_ds_loc), vi.dc_info.ref) self._move_to_cache(self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, tmp_image_ds_loc.parent, vi.cache_image_folder) # The size of the image is different from the size of the virtual # disk. We want to use the latter. self._update_image_size(vi) def _update_image_size(self, vi): """Updates the file size of the specified image.""" # The size of the Glance image is different from the deployed VMDK # size for sparse, streamOptimized and OVA images. We need to retrieve # the size of the flat VMDK and update the file_size property of the # image. This ensures that further operations involving size checks # and disk resizing will work as expected. ds_browser = self._get_ds_browser(vi.datastore.ref) flat_file = "%s-flat.vmdk" % vi.ii.image_id new_size = ds_util.file_size(self._session, ds_browser, vi.cache_image_folder, flat_file) if new_size is not None: vi.ii.file_size = new_size class StreamOptimizedImage(Image): """Stream optimized image as a vApp.""" def _prepare_image(self, vi): vm_name = "%s_%s" % (constants.IMAGE_VM_PREFIX, uuidutils.generate_uuid()) tmp_dir_loc = vi.datastore.build_path(vm_name) tmp_image_ds_loc = tmp_dir_loc.join("%s.vmdk" % tmp_dir_loc.basename) return tmp_dir_loc, tmp_image_ds_loc def _cache_image(self, vi, tmp_image_ds_loc): dst_path = vi.cache_image_folder.join("%s.vmdk" % vi.ii.image_id) ds_util.mkdir(self._session, vi.cache_image_folder, vi.dc_info.ref) try: ds_util.disk_move(self._session, vi.dc_info.ref, tmp_image_ds_loc, dst_path) except vexc.FileAlreadyExistsException: pass def _get_upload_handle(self, context, image_ref, target): LOG.debug("Downloading image file data %(image_ref)s to the ESX " "as VM named '%(vm_name)s'", {'image_ref': image_ref, 'vm_name': target.vm_name}) session = self._session metadata = IMAGE_API.get(context, image_ref) file_size = int(metadata['size']) vm_import_spec = self._build_vm_import_spec( session, target.vm_name, target.ds_name) write_handle = rw_handles.VmdkWriteHandle(session, target.host, target.port, target.res_pool_ref, target.vm_folder_ref, vm_import_spec, file_size) return write_handle, file_size def _post_fetch_image(self, context, instance, target, write_handle=None, write_handle=None): session = self._session imported_vm_ref = write_handle.get_imported_vm() LOG.info(_LI("Downloaded image file data %(image_ref)s"), {'image_ref': instance.image_ref}, instance=instance) vmdk = vm_util.get_vmdk_info(session, imported_vm_ref, target.vm_name) session._call_method(session.vim, "UnregisterVM", imported_vm_ref) LOG.info(_LI("The imported VM was unregistered"), instance=instance) return vmdk.capacity_in_bytes @staticmethod def _build_shadow_vm_config_spec(session, name, size_kb, disk_type, ds_name): """Return spec for creating a shadow VM for image disk. The VM is never meant to be powered on. When used in importing a disk it governs the directory name created for the VM and the disk type of the disk image to convert to. :param name: Name of the backing :param size_kb: Size in KB of the backing :param disk_type: VMDK type for the disk :param ds_name: Datastore name where the disk is to be provisioned :return: Spec for creation """ cf = session.vim.client.factory controller_device = cf.create('ns0:VirtualLsiLogicController') controller_device.key = -100 controller_device.busNumber = 0 controller_device.sharedBus = 'noSharing' controller_spec = cf.create('ns0:VirtualDeviceConfigSpec') controller_spec.operation = 'add' controller_spec.device = controller_device disk_device = cf.create('ns0:VirtualDisk') # for very small disks allocate at least 1KB disk_device.capacityInKB = max(1, int(size_kb)) disk_device.key = -101 disk_device.unitNumber = 0 disk_device.controllerKey = -100 disk_device_bkng = cf.create('ns0:VirtualDiskFlatVer2BackingInfo') if disk_type == constants.DISK_TYPE_EAGER_ZEROED_THICK: disk_device_bkng.eagerlyScrub = True elif disk_type == constants.DISK_TYPE_THIN: disk_device_bkng.thinProvisioned = True disk_device_bkng.fileName = '[%s]' % ds_name disk_device_bkng.diskMode = 'persistent' disk_device.backing = disk_device_bkng disk_spec = cf.create('ns0:VirtualDeviceConfigSpec') disk_spec.operation = 'add' disk_spec.fileOperation = 'create' disk_spec.device = disk_device vm_file_info = cf.create('ns0:VirtualMachineFileInfo') vm_file_info.vmPathName = '[%s]' % ds_name create_spec = cf.create('ns0:VirtualMachineConfigSpec') create_spec.name = name create_spec.guestId = constants.DEFAULT_OS_TYPE create_spec.numCPUs = 1 create_spec.memoryMB = 128 create_spec.deviceChange = [controller_spec, disk_spec] create_spec.files = vm_file_info return create_spec @staticmethod def _build_vm_import_spec(session, vm_name, datastore_name): """Build VirtualMachineImportSpec for import vApp""" vm_create_spec = StreamOptimizedImage._build_shadow_vm_config_spec( session, vm_name, 0, constants.DISK_TYPE_THIN, datastore_name) client_factory = session.vim.client.factory vm_import_spec = client_factory.create('ns0:VirtualMachineImportSpec') vm_import_spec.configSpec = vm_create_spec return vm_import_spec class OvaImage(Image): def _do_fetch_image(self, context, instance, target): """Download the OVA image from the glance image server to the Nova compute node. """ session = self._session image_ref = instance.image_ref vm_name = target.vm_name LOG.debug("Downloading OVA image file %(image_ref)s to the ESX " "as VM named '%(vm_name)s'", {'image_ref': image_ref, 'vm_name': vm_name}, instance=instance) metadata = IMAGE_API.get(context, image_ref) file_size = int(metadata['size']) vm_import_spec = StreamOptimizedImage._build_vm_import_spec( session, target.vm_name, target.ds_name) read_iter = IMAGE_API.download(context, image_ref) read_handle = rw_handles.ImageReadHandle(read_iter) with tarfile.open(mode="r|", fileobj=read_handle) as tar: vmdk_name = None for tar_info in tar: if tar_info and tar_info.name.endswith(".ovf"): extracted = tar.extractfile(tar_info) xmlstr = extracted.read() vmdk_name = self.get_vmdk_name_from_ovf(xmlstr) elif vmdk_name and tar_info.name.startswith(vmdk_name): # Actual file name is <vmdk_name>.XXXXXXX extracted = tar.extractfile(tar_info) write_handle = rw_handles.VmdkWriteHandle( session, target.host, target.port, target.res_pool_ref, target.vm_folder_ref, vm_import_spec, file_size) start_transfer(context, extracted, file_size, write_file_handle=write_handle) extracted.close() LOG.info(_LI("Downloaded OVA image file %(image_ref)s"), {'image_ref': instance.image_ref}, instance=instance) imported_vm_ref = write_handle.get_imported_vm() vmdk = vm_util.get_vmdk_info(session, imported_vm_ref, vm_name) session._call_method(session.vim, "UnregisterVM", imported_vm_ref) LOG.info(_LI("The imported VM was unregistered"), instance=instance) return vmdk.capacity_in_bytes raise exception.ImageUnacceptable( reason=_("Extracting vmdk from OVA failed."), image_id=image_ref) @staticmethod def get_vmdk_name_from_ovf(xmlstr): """Parse the OVA descriptor to extract the vmdk name.""" ovf = etree.fromstring(xmlstr) nsovf = "{%s}" % ovf.nsmap["ovf"] disk = ovf.find("./%sDiskSection/%sDisk" % (nsovf, nsovf)) file_id = disk.get("%sfileRef" % nsovf) file = ovf.find('./%sReferences/%sFile[@%sid="%s"]' % (nsovf, nsovf, nsovf, file_id)) vmdk_name = file.get("%shref" % nsovf) return vmdk_name def vmware_image_from_image(image_id, image_meta, **kwargs): """Returns an instance of VMwareImage subclass. :param image_id - image id of image :param image_meta - image metadata object we are working with :return: vmware image object :rtype: nova.virt.vmwareapi.images.VmwareImage """ def _get_vmware_image(props): image = VMwareImage(**props) disk_type = image.disk_type props.update({'session': kwargs['session'], 'volumeops': kwargs['volumeops'], 'tmp_folder': kwargs['tmp_folder'], 'get_ds_browser': kwargs['get_ds_browser'], 'check_cache_folder': kwargs['check_cache_folder']}) if image.is_ova: # TODO: Check how OVA prepare_image and cache_image image = OvaImage(**props) elif image.is_iso: image = IsoImage(**props) elif disk_type == constants.DISK_TYPE_SPARSE: image = SparseImage(**props) elif disk_type == constants.DISK_TYPE_STREAM_OPTIMIZED: image = StreamOptimizedImage(**props) elif disk_type in constants.SUPPORTED_FLAT_VARIANTS: image = FlatImage(**props) else: reason = _("disk type '%s' not supported") % disk_type raise exception.InvalidDiskInfo(reason=reason) return image properties = image_meta.properties # calculate linked_clone flag, allow image properties to override the # global property set in the configurations. image_linked_clone = properties.get('img_linked_clone', CONF.vmware.use_linked_clone) # catch any string values that need to be interpreted as boolean values linked_clone = strutils.bool_from_string(image_linked_clone) if image_meta.obj_attr_is_set('container_format'): container_format = image_meta.container_format else: container_format = None props = { 'image_id': image_id, 'linked_clone': linked_clone, 'container_format': container_format } if image_meta.obj_attr_is_set('size'): props['file_size'] = image_meta.size if image_meta.obj_attr_is_set('disk_format'): props['file_type'] = image_meta.disk_format hw_disk_bus = properties.get('hw_disk_bus') if hw_disk_bus: mapping = { fields.SCSIModel.LSILOGIC: constants.DEFAULT_ADAPTER_TYPE, fields.SCSIModel.LSISAS1068: constants.ADAPTER_TYPE_LSILOGICSAS, fields.SCSIModel.BUSLOGIC: constants.ADAPTER_TYPE_BUSLOGIC, fields.SCSIModel.VMPVSCSI: constants.ADAPTER_TYPE_PARAVIRTUAL, } if hw_disk_bus == fields.DiskBus.IDE: props['adapter_type'] = constants.ADAPTER_TYPE_IDE elif hw_disk_bus == fields.DiskBus.SCSI: hw_scsi_model = properties.get('hw_scsi_model') props['adapter_type'] = mapping.get(hw_scsi_model) props_map = { 'os_distro': 'os_type', 'hw_disk_type': 'disk_type', 'hw_vif_model': 'vif_model' } for k, v in six.iteritems(props_map): if properties.obj_attr_is_set(k): props[v] = properties.get(k) return _get_vmware_image(props)

subject: WIP: Eventually consistent host state prototype
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-15 02:49:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3ab688d481a11fb76b1ab4684fbb65560805df80', 'message': 'WIP: Eventually consistent host state prototype

This patch is a conceptual implementation of bp
eventually-consistent-scheduler-host-state to testify its design goals
in accuracy, performance, reliability and compatibility improvements.

To run and test this prototype, download this patch and set
`scheduler_host_manager=shared_host_manager` in "nova.conf". Do not
forget to update "nova/nova.egg-info/entry_points.txt" according to the
modified "setup.cfg". Also note: Multiple scheduler instances can only
run on separate machines, and this prototype supports filter schedulers
and caching schedulers running at the same time.

In order to be flexible with design changes and quick prototyping, there
are still no unit tests. They will be added once the general idea is
accepted and the design is confirmed with spec.

If you find any bugs, please paste your detailed log information to
http://paste.openstack.org/ and reply here.

Please refer to the summit session if you are interested in this:
https://www.openstack.org/summit/austin-2016/vote-for-speakers/Presentation/7316

Related to blueprint eventually-consistent-scheduler-host-state
Change-Id: I6432197c0c52a445f75d5d801fe8722e67da1aff
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-15 05:33:30.000000000', 'files': ['nova/filters.py', 'nova/scheduler/manager.py', 'nova/scheduler/scheduler_server.py', 'nova/scheduler/client/__init__.py', 'nova/scheduler/driver.py', 'nova/claims.py', 'nova/scheduler/cache_manager.py', 'nova/objects/host_state.py', 'nova/scheduler/scheduler_client.py', 'nova/scheduler/filter_scheduler.py', 'nova/scheduler/client/query.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py', 'nova/compute/rpcapi.py', 'nova/scheduler/rpcapi.py', 'nova/scheduler/filters/disk_filter.py', 'nova/cmd/scheduler.py', 'nova/objects/__init__.py', 'nova/objects/fields.py', 'nova/compute/claims.py', 'nova/virt/hardware.py', 'nova/scheduler/shared_state_manager.py', 'nova/conductor/manager.py', 'setup.cfg', 'nova/compute/resource_tracker.py', 'nova/scheduler/host_manager.py', 'nova/scheduler/claims.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/290f209fc8d69054141726a7f625924cf0583853', 'message': 'WIP: Eventually consistent host state prototype

commit_message:
WIP: Eventually consistent host state prototype

This patch is a conceptual implementation of bp
eventually-consistent-scheduler-host-state to testify its design goals
in accuracy, performance, reliability and compatibility improvements.

To run and test this prototype, download this patch and set
`scheduler_host_manager=shared_host_manager` in "nova.conf". Do not
forget to update "nova/nova.egg-info/entry_points.txt" according to the
modified "setup.cfg". Also note: Multiple scheduler instances can only
run on separate machines, and this prototype supports filter schedulers
and caching schedulers running at the same time.

In order to be flexible with design changes and quick prototyping, there
are still no unit tests. They will be added once the general idea is
accepted and the design is confirmed with spec.

For discussions and detailed explanation, please refer to the maillist:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-February/086516.html

If you find any bugs, please paste your detailed log information to
http://paste.openstack.org/ and reply here.

Please refer to the summit session if you are interested:
https://www.openstack.org/summit/austin-2016/vote-for-speakers/Presentation/7316

Related to blueprint eventually-consistent-scheduler-host-state

commit_message:
virt/libvirt: Consider live-resize limits when booting an instance

Retrieve live-resize limits for memory and vcpus from flavor and
set vcpu and maxMemory values in domain xml accordingly.

Change-Id: I97790ea83d8194c750aa6afe1cf65c8ba2591fda
Partially-Implements: blueprint instance-live-resize

commit_message:
Implement images list default and maximum limit

Limit image listings the same as server and flavor listings, as the
documentation states [1], by modifying get_pagination_params(), so
that it actually does what its docstring states [2], and adjust
get_limit_and_marker() to account for the underlying change.

[1] "To reduce load on the service, list operations return a maximum
    number of items at a time. The maximum number of items returned is
    determined by the compute provider."
    http://docs.openstack.org/developer/nova/v2/paginated_collections.html

[2] "If 'limit' is not specified, 0, or > max_limit, we default to
    max_limit."

Change-Id: I9bdb649362a5ad0c5fdb0f3836ad0991b1de9887

subject: NoVNC: Allow Origin header protocols on a per-host basis
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-10 23:55:45.000000000', 'files': ['nova/console/websocketproxy.py', 'nova/tests/unit/console/test_websocketproxy.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/e2e1c6177cccc6a866dc8b75bcafff2a6c0dcf44', 'message': "NoVNC: Allow Origin header protocols on a per-host basis

While `console_allowed_origins` allows for additional allowed `Origin`
header hosts, it doesn't allow the `Origin` header protocol to deviate
from the protocol in the published service URL.

`console_allowed_origin_protocols` specifies additional `Origin`
header protocols that are allowed on a per-host basis.

    [DEFAULT]
    console_allowed_origins = www.example.com,dev.example.com,localhost
    console_allowed_origin_protocols = localhost:http

This allows web developers to work on noVNC web interfaces served over
HTTP from their local computers which directs the web browser to a
noVNC proxy that uses HTTPS (while www.example.com and dev.example.com
must use the same protocol as the noVNC proxy, presumably HTTPS).

Change-Id: Id8d2ded9b4bd81f312c1b746e8ad719ed7a0644b
"}]
commit_message:
NoVNC: Allow Origin header protocols on a per-host basis

While `console_allowed_origins` allows for additional allowed `Origin`
header hosts, it doesn't allow the `Origin` header protocol to deviate
from the protocol in the published service URL.

`console_allowed_origin_protocols` specifies additional `Origin`
header protocols that are allowed on a per-host basis.

    [DEFAULT]
    console_allowed_origins = www.example.com,dev.example.com,localhost
    console_allowed_origin_protocols = localhost:http

This allows web developers to work on noVNC web interfaces served over
HTTP from their local computers which directs the web browser to a
noVNC proxy that uses HTTPS (while www.example.com and dev.example.com
must use the same protocol as the noVNC proxy, presumably HTTPS).

Change-Id: Id8d2ded9b4bd81f312c1b746e8ad719ed7a0644b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/00/278800/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Compute: Check live-resize constraints

Check that live-resize constraints are met before resizing:
1.The maximum limit of resources in the target falavor is
less than current flavor.
2.Live resize of resources are allowed in image metadata.

Change-Id: I61b57887cdccf8b9673c47497f4a7f00a0b4fe61
Partially-Implements: blueprint instance-live-resize
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/84/276884/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova.i18n import _from nova.virt import hardwaredef check_can_live_resize(context, instance, instance_type, image): """Check if live-resize constraints are met. Live-resize is going to be constrained by the following: 1.The maximum limit of resources in the target falavor is less than current flavor. 2.Live resize of resources are allowed in image metadata. This functions will be called by live_resize_instance. """ # Get the system metadata from the instance system_meta = utils.instance_sys_meta(instance) # Convert the system metadata to image metadata meta = utils.get_image_from_system_metadata(system_meta) if not meta: image_ref = instance.get('image_ref') meta = compute_utils.get_image_metadata(context, self._image_api, image_ref, instance) image_meta = objects.ImageMeta.from_dict(meta) old_instance_type = objects.Flavor.get_by_id( context, instance['instance_type_id']) old_limits = hardware.get_live_resize_constraints(old_instance_type, image_meta) limits = hardware.get_live_resize_constraints(instance_type, image_meta) violations = list() if limits['max_vcpus'] > old_limits['max_vcpus']: violations.append('max_vcpus') if limits['max_memory'] > old_limits['max_memory']: violations.append('max_memory') if limits['max_memory_slots'] > old_limits['max_memory_slots']: violations.append('max_memory_slots') if violations: raise exception.NovaException( _("cannot live-resize to a flavor with greater limits " " for %(resources)s") % {'resources': violations}) delta = hardware.get_live_resize_resource_delta(old_instance_type, instance_type, image_meta) disallowed = [rsrc for rsrc in delta.keys() if rsrc not in limits['resizeable']] if disallowed: raise exception.NovaException( _("live-resize is not allowed for %(resources)s") % {'resources': disallowed})

commit_message:
Libvirt: live-resize vcpus without NUMA

Perfrom live-resize of vcpus for guests without NUMA topolgy.
Memory live-resize will not be supported for guests without NUMA.
Disk live-resize will be implemented by a separate delivery.

Change-Id: Ieed6cd08ffb37067221ce61cf78feb422d7d22dc
Partially-Implements: blueprint instance-live-resize

commit_message:
Libvirt: Add methods to parse domain metadata from xml

Add methods to parse the domain metadata from xml into LibvirtConfig
classes. This is needed to update the flavor information in the
domains metadata following a live-resize operation.

Change-Id: I9b6bead807052eccca8df0455ed0151f4f38a200
Partially-Implements: blueprint instance-live-resize

commit_message:
objects: Adds os_live_resize field to ImageMetaProps

The image metadata property os_live_resize is a set of
live-resizable resources supported by the guest. It is
mandatory for the live-resize operation.

Change-Id: I90b8068452b9f555384eeb78e451aadd2ebab0e4
Partially-Implements: blueprint instance-live-resize

added_lines: # Version 1.9: Added `os_live_resize' field VERSION = '1.9' if target_version < (1, 9): primitive.pop('os_live_resize', None) # set - contains a set of live-resizable resources supported by the # guest OS. This field is mandatory for the live-resize operation. 'os_live_resize': fields.LiveResizeField(),
deleted_lines: VERSION = '1.8'

mock_set_metadata.call_args[0][1]) self.assertIn("<nova:vcpus>4</nova:vcpus>", mock_set_metadata.call_args[0][1])

commit_message:
Allows to set display_name as instance_name

This patch adds option in nova.conf to ignore the
user input for instance name and set the display_name
same as the instance_name. It also add the relevant
code to set instance display_name to instance_name.

Implements: blueprint instance-display-name

Change-Id: I563af3e790aa2b9cbbf9c265ce1bbe48106c0708
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/53/263353/16 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: CONF.import_opt('instance_display_name', 'nova.db.api') def _apply_instance_name_template_for_display_name(self, context, instance): try: new_name = (CONF.instance_name_template % instance['id']) except (ValueError, TypeError): LOG.exception(_LE('Failed to set instance name using ' 'instance_name_template.')) new_name = instance['display_name'] instance.display_name = new_name instance.save() return instance elif CONF.instance_display_name == 1: # instance_name_template is used to assign instance_name as # display_name for instance if set in config file. instance = self._apply_instance_name_template_for_display_name( context, instance)

commit_message:
add job to apply tags when based on changes in openstack/releases

Add a new job to run when a patch merges in openstack/releases to apply
the tags described in the patch. For now, only apply those tags to the
openstack/release-test repository so we can test the job. A later patch
will remove that restriction so the job can apply the tags to all
repositories.

Change-Id: I2121781197d3ed824fed91cdebd0ee9ebeb353d2
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/58/341058/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - job: name: tag-releases description: Apply tags to repositories based on changes in deliverables files. node: signing builders: - gerrit-git-prep - revoke-sudo - shell: | #!/bin/bash -ex # Pass the location of the openstack/releases repo to # release_from_yaml.sh explicitly so it knows where to scan to # look for modified files. /usr/local/jenkins/slave_scripts/release-tools $(pwd) publishers: - scp: site: 'static.openstack.org' files: - target: 'logs/$LOG_PATH' source: 'cover/**' keep-hierarchy: true copy-after-failure: true - console-log

Bump microversion to 2.31 for deprecated proxy APIs

This is the final patch for deprecation of proxy APIs.

commit_message:
Replace deprecated LOG.warn with LOG.warning

LOG.warn is deprecated. It is still used in few modules.
Replaced with non-deprecated LOG.warning.

Change-Id: If18dfd975eb5977f0ac249c3386ebd242d4e0ecc
Partial-Bug: #1508442
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/16/343216/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.warning(_LW("One or more image locations couldn't be " "scrubbed from backend. Leaving image '%s' in " "'pending_delete' status") % image_id)
deleted_lines: LOG.warn(_LW("One or more image locations couldn't be scrubbed " "from backend. Leaving image '%s' in 'pending_delete'" " status") % image_id)

subject: Nested Quota Driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-11-06 20:56:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/77c8aded9b8d53186e25309e04cb0701f7aa470d', 'message': "Nested Quota Driver

Nested Quota Driver patch adds hierarchical support. Quota
API's now can also handle hierarchical projects.

For the first pass only a user with admin role in a parent project
will be able to update and delete its children quotas.

Even after these changes are made, the existing DbQuotaDriver
functionalities will remain unchanged. The same driver will be able to
handle flat projects as well as hierarchical projects.

Co-Authored-By: Raildo Mascena <raildo@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>
Co-Authored-By: Sajeesh CS <sajeesh.cs@cern.ch>
Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>

Partially Implements:  bp nested-quota-driver-api

Change-Id: I18ce5dce266bfc0fd6d3019dc572bf82d6e02cdc

commit_message:
Nested Quota Driver

Nested Quota Driver patch adds hierarchical support. Quota
API's now can also handle hierarchical projects.

For the first pass only a user with admin role in a parent project
will be able to update and delete its children quotas.

Even after these changes are made, the existing DbQuotaDriver
functionalities will remain unchanged. The same driver will be able to
handle flat projects as well as hierarchical projects.

Co-Authored-By: Raildo Mascena <raildo@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>
Co-Authored-By: Sajeesh CS <sajeesh.cs@cern.ch>
Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>

Partially Implements:  bp nested-quota-driver-api

Change-Id: I18ce5dce266bfc0fd6d3019dc572bf82d6e02cdc

commit_message:
WIP Allow modification of delete_on_termination

Add a microversion to allow the delete_on_termination attribute of a
volume attachment (block device mapping) to be updated by the
os-volume_attachments API.

The current implementation of the update action allows the user to
swap which volume is attached on a volume attachment.  This change
allows the user to set the delete_on_termination value, swap the
volume, or both.

Related to blueprint delete-on-termination-modification
APIImpact

Change-Id: I92b9c337604b7d5ec1cdea143f7ccd2914513724

commit_message:
Cells RAM/IP combined weigher

This introduces a weigher that takes both RAM and IP availability in a
cell into account. It bases the resulting weight on the limiting factor
of the two. Decrementing is also used to approximate results in case
there is a burst of builds between multiple schedulers. Further, the
maximum number of builds a cell can support based on max IO ops and max
instances is accounted for.

Implements: blueprint cells-concurrent-builds

Change-Id: Ifec5f36db6991e74540e362a3ee8f54c7d9cea0a

commit_message:
Listing volumes does not provide a link to next element

When GETting os-volumes, the returned list of volumes respects the
osapi_max_limit configuration parameter but does not provide a link to
the next element in the list.

DocImpact
Implements: blueprint add-resources-links
Change-Id: Id14a87a8fefab0b7a403385808d6a19553b37db3
Closes-Bug: 1504641

commit_message:
Add sriov info for live migration

This patch tries to add sriov mechanism to the live
migration with following points:
 - generate sriov info in the pre_live_migration logic
 - update the sriov xml during the live migration executing

Change-Id: I78fbcbdcd2a0cb53aa1f12a25de2a1d20c003ac2
Implements: blueprint sriov-live-migration

commit_message:
Add checking logic for sriov migration

Currently, only macvtap migration will be supported,
so we will raise exception if there are some direct
sriov ports attached on the instance and then terminate
the migration operation.

Change-Id: I155a952e942f8b234797063043d29ce4e49c36b4
Implements: blueprint sriov-live-migration

commit_message:
Nested Quota: Set default values to subproject

In case of hierarchical projects set the default value
(for resources who have the resource flag set) for a
sub-project to zero. This patch adds this functionality for
hierarchical projects, while keeping the functionality
intact for non-hierarchical project. At the top level,
project resources will get the default values as imposed
by the "default" class settings.

Co-Authored-By: Raildo Mascena <raildo@lsd.ufcg.edu.br>
Co-Authored-By: Sajeesh CS <sajeesh.cs@cern.ch>
Co-Authored-By: Vilobh Meshram <vilobhmm@yahoo-inc.com>

Partially Implements:  bp nested-quota-driver-api

Change-Id: I326a81957ef78f85ba35345b4c64fae456ad5ffc

commit_message:
Make the create_instance call accept security group ids as well as names

Since it's possible to have multiple security groups with the same name,
we need a way of specifying the groups by id instead. This change makes
it still accept names (for backward compatibility), but treats them as
ids when they are simple numbers.

Change-Id: I0025893535837ebcd53e9fdcc7dc71c509fe0988
Closes-bug: #1289195

commit_message:
libvirt:Code refactoring

1. Removed sleep(1) after last iteration in reboot virtual machine operation.
2. Refactored loop in _hard_reboot() method.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: I04350c8b46563195629b5defc30fea2876b2131a

commit_message:
Ensure _cleanup_deploy is called even if _unprovision raises

This change ensures that _cleanup_deploy gets called, even in the face
of _unprovision raising an exception. Solves a bug where ironic's virt
driver neglects to delete an instance's ID in ironic, even though nova expects
the instance to be cleared in ironic.

Change-Id: I8d61fe4200aa826c29b7b144c9f7e892c519f6df

commit_message:
Barbican-Cinder: Restart c-api instead of c-vol

To apply the new configuraiton options, the cinder-api
service needs to be restarted instead of the cinder-volume
service.

Change-Id: I3b410848bfe9c9b64f8cf802106e17583d006293
Closes-Bug: #1582655
(cherry picked from commit cca20b9d6a9015a5e771f4fea007e7b6a4a37ae9)

commit_message:
tox: add py35 envs for convenience

py35 jobs are going to be run in the gate soon. Add py35 to the list
of defaut envs and add corresponding pifpaf environments for running
tests locally.

All py35 tests currently pass - we can effectively declare py35
compatibility via a new classifier in setup.cfg.

subject: Make os-net-config idempotent with Linux bonds and MAC mapping
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-30 23:02:13.000000000', 'files': ['os_net_config/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/os-net-config/commit/6036a166710b22831b0ec9756b9732024b0a0e24', 'message': "Make os-net-config idempotent with Linux bonds and MAC mapping

This small change fixes a serious bug in os-net-config which made
mapping NICs by MAC address not idempotent if Linux bonds were used.

The first time os-net-config runs, it sees the MAC address of each
interface, then it sets up the bond. On subsequent runs, any
non-primary interfaces have taken the MAC address of the primary
interface in the bond. At this time, they all show the same MAC
address. This causes the mapping to fail, and it appears that
the system has fewer matching interfaces than it had before.

The impact of this bug is that bonding doesn't work for
anyone doing mapping by MAC address. This is known to be affecting
installations with a particular 3rd-party Neutron plugin vendor.

This change simply looks for the permanent hardware address under
the bonding_slave directory, if it exists.

Change-Id: I5b0087370f74ecc319d2285b0f9f5f3dd951dbc2
"}]
commit_message:
Make os-net-config idempotent with Linux bonds and MAC mapping

This small change fixes a serious bug in os-net-config which made
mapping NICs by MAC address not idempotent if Linux bonds were used.

The first time os-net-config runs, it sees the MAC address of each
interface, then it sets up the bond. On subsequent runs, any
non-primary interfaces have taken the MAC address of the primary
interface in the bond. At this time, they all show the same MAC
address. This causes the mapping to fail, and it appears that
the system has fewer matching interfaces than it had before.

The impact of this bug is that bonding doesn't work for
anyone doing mapping by MAC address. This is known to be affecting
installations with a particular 3rd-party Neutron plugin vendor.

This change simply looks for the permanent hardware address under
the bonding_slave directory, if it exists.

Change-Id: I5b0087370f74ecc319d2285b0f9f5f3dd951dbc2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-net-config refs/changes/13/336313/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: # If the iface is part of a Linux bond, the real MAC is only here. with open('/sys/class/net/%s/bonding_slave/perm_hwaddr' % name, 'r') as f: return f.read().rstrip() except IOError: pass # Iface is not part of a bond, continue

commit_message:
update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0. Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: I27348462a21daab479d76b24b48e3a4e017504cc
(cherry picked from commit 0b59a910fb8d614f9503b7921edf196e6f908a37)

commit_message:
PoC: Understandable weighers

Make the weighers more unserstandable for operators and easier to
deploy. A new weigher and placement algorithm that is easier to
understand in operation and has far fewer configuraion options while
still making good placment decisions.

Change-Id: If4fee90541f15e7286e6daefb14b8021bb1ac8e4

commit_message:
First pass at fix for bug #1604187

There are differences between requestslib's PreparedRequest and
Syntribos' RequestObject, which can cause problems when they are used
inconsistently.

This is a first pass at a fix, editing BaseTestCase's send_init_request
to add the body to the test.init_req object.

Change-Id: I6f71fb52bca2f1cccdbdbce5f081431a0750db66
Partial-Bug: #1604187

commit_message:
added CLI option to exclude tests from runner

-e, --excluded-types is now a CLI option to do the opposite of -t. That is,
syntribos -e SQL will now exclude all SQL injection tests from being run.

Change-Id: I2f9a0da9792e17bfb8777e9497fc9c5dcbfe9660

commit_message:
Use bundletester for amulet test execution

Switch to using bundletester for execution of functional tests,
leveraging tox to build out test virtualenvs.

Rename amulet tests inline with gate-* and dfs-* naming standards.

Update README to refer to functional testing section of the charm
guide.

Change-Id: I218411054a00ef80ef56da72ef20785e31f1b69c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-swift-proxy refs/changes/14/344114/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:func27-noop] # DRY RUN - For Debug basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "gate-*" -n --no-destroy [testenv:func27] # Charm Functional Test # Run all gate tests which are +x (expected to always pass) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "gate-*" --no-destroy [testenv:func27-smoke] # Charm Functional Test # Run a specific test as an Amulet smoke test (expected to always pass) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json gate-basic-xenial-mitaka --no-destroy [testenv:func27-dfs] # Charm Functional Test # Run all deploy-from-source tests which are +x (may not always pass!) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "dfs-*" --no-destroy [testenv:func27-dev] # Charm Functional Test # Run all development test targets which are +x (may not always pass!) basepython = python2.7 deps = -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt commands = bundletester -vl DEBUG -r json -o func-results.json --test-pattern "dev-*" --no-destroy

Request local cache only used msgpack due to the complex structure

'}]
commit_message:
Change to use json instead of msgpack in request_local cache

Request local cache only used msgpack due to the complex structure
of the revocation events tree. Since the tree is now removed, this
can be moved over to using JSON (which is significantly faster than
msgpack at a minimal memory consumption cost).

Change-Id: Id8820f36042d80e3855e093417805765f29898e7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/88/314188/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_serialization import jsonutils setattr(ctx, self._get_request_key(key), jsonutils.dumps(serialize)) value = jsonutils.loads(value)
deleted_lines: from oslo_serialization import msgpackutils setattr(ctx, self._get_request_key(key), msgpackutils.dumps(serialize)) value = msgpackutils.loads(value)
